Class 5 Science: Different Types of Animals 
How many different animals can you name? 
List them with a partner.

What are the differences between these animals?
Take your list and put them into groups with your partner.
What were the categories you chose for the groups?

Think: How can you classify your animals into only 2 groups?
Read the lesson to find out how scientists decided to make 
categories for animals and what the 2 main groups are!

What are the main differences between: 

A human and a snail?
A snake and a worm?
A whale and a fish?

You choose two different animals to compare!
What characteristics make them the same or different?

Identify Types of Vertebrates vs. Invertebrates: 

All animals fit into two classes: vertebrates and invertebrates.

Vertebrates: Have backbones: Examples: Humans, Whales, Dogs
Invertebrates: Do not have backbones: Examples: Spiders, Worms,
 Snails

Look at the following pictures of animals. 
Identify each as vertebrate or invertebrate
If it is a vertebrate: identify it as a 
Mammal, Aves (bird), Reptile, Amphibia, or Pisces (fish)

Reflection/ Learn More: 

Discuss:
Why do you think some animals have backbones, but others don't?
Did you notice a difference between large animals and small animals?
Or between land animals and aquatic animals?

Do you have any questions? Write them down.
Look at the next 3 slides for articles on 
Vertebrates, Invertebrates, and Mammals.
(You can look up other categories through Looma Wikipedia too.)

Activity: Animal Classification Chart 

Make an Animal Classification Chart for your classroom to show the 
categories from your lesson and that uses your lists of animals.
Include animals you have seen where you live!

All can be under 1. Vertebrate and 2. Invertebrate. 
Then...What are the sub-categories under each?

Each student can choose different animals to draw, label, and 
display.
Try to make your class diagram accurate, colorful, and creative!

Class 4 Science: Energy 

       What is energy?
       What are some of the different types of energy?
       What are ways you use energy?
       Try to do the experiments to make discoveries.

Heat Energy: 

The Sun is our main source of heat energy.
When we heat matter, its volume increases.
When we cool matter, its volume decreases.

What happens to water when we heat it?
What happens to water when we cool it?
What happens to metal when we heat it?
Discuss the next two slides.

States of Matter: 

There are three states of matter:

                      1) Solid (ice)
                      2) Liquid (water)
                      3) Gas (steam)

When we transfer heat energy to ice, it becomes water.  
      When we heat water, it becomes steam.

What do we need energy for?

Discuss some examples

Different Sources of Energy: 

Watch two videos to learn about different sources of energy.
People can get energy from coal and oil.

    What are some problems with using coal and oil?
    What are other sources of energy?

    Notice: electric power, hydropower (water),solar power (sun),
             and nuclear power.

What are some of the ways we can CONSERVE energy?

     1) turn off electric lights or appliances when not in use
     2) use pressure cooker to cook food
     3) limit the use of vehicles that use gasoline
     4) put out fire after use to conserve coal or firewood

What ideas do you have?

Reading and Research 

What questions do you have about energy?

The next 3 slides have more information about 3 topics:
Energy, Coal, and Electricity

        Write questions about these three topics.

Plants and Animals 

Objective: at the end of this lesson, students will:
   
      1. identify the basic characteristics of plants and animals;

      2. understand their basic needs;

      3. recognize the difference between the two.

Opener
     
     What do you know about plants?

     What do you know about animals?

     Can you identify some basic similarities and differences between
          the two?

     How are plants different from animals?

Here are pictures of animals and plants.

What are the names of all of the ones you know?

Write down the different colors you see.

Are there pictures with both plants and animals?

Exploration: Plants and Animals 

On the whiteboard, make 2 columns. Write 'Plants' above one and
'Animals' above the other.

 Make a list of what plants and animals need to live. 

 How are they the same and how are they different? (Think about
 what they eat, whether they move, how they grow.)

Exploration: Plants and Animals 

What do plants and animals need to live?
Possible answers:
Plants           Animals
sunlight
air
food
water


 How are they the same and how are they different? (Think about
 what they eat, whether they move, how they grow.)

Exploration: Plants and Animals 
But plants and animals are different. 
1. Plants grow from seeds and make their own food using their
   leaves to help them make food. This process is called 
               photosynthesis. 
   Animals cannot make their own food. They eat other organisms 
for energy and nutrients. 
2. Plants are stationary; roots hold them in the ground.
Animals move around. They have wings, or legs, or bodies that 
slither, like snakes.
3. Plants have flowers or fruits that produce seeds for new plants.
Animals have families. Some live in herds, packs, or flocks.

Plants and Animals Assessment 

How does a plant get food? How does an animal get food?

What do both need in order to live?

How do plants and animals move differently?

  Draw a picture of an animal and its basic needs.
Draw a picture of a plant and its basic needs.

Class 1: Animals Take Food 

Food: any substance people or animals eat or drink in order to live

What is your favorite food?

Why do we eat food?

What would happen to us if we didn't eat?

Questions 

What do you think the bird is doing?

Answer 

What do you think the bird is doing?

The bird is going to eat the snake. He is hungry.

           All animals need to eat food to survive.

Questions 

Why is the mouse running?

What is the cat doing?

Answers 

The mouse is running because he is afraid of being caught 
by the cat. We call him the prey.

The cat is chasing the mouse because he wants to eat him.
We call him the predator.

An animal can be both a prey and a predator. Can you think of 
some examples?

Answers 

An animal can be both a prey and a predator. Here are some 
examples:

  1. A snake is a predator to a mouse, but prey to an eagle.

2. A large fish is a predator to a small fish, but prey to a whale.

Gecko 

Look at how long this gecko's tongue is. Is your tongue that long?

Why does a gecko need such a long tongue?

Reflection 

Do you think all animals eat?

Why do you think they have to eat?

Do you think some animals eat other animals?

Class 1 Science: Plants 

Let's learn about plants!

What do you know about plants?

Do you eat plants?

Do you grow plants?

What do plants give us?

Plants give us shelter, food and air.

What do plants need?

Plants live and grow, just like you!

The next video will show you.

How do plants grow? 

Plants start out as seeds.
           When they are planted, they grow and become sprouts
           growing out of the seed.

With enough of what they need, they
get bigger and create their own seeds.

What do you think plants need in order to grow?

Have you ever grown a plant?

How long did it take for it to grow?

Watch a plant grow in the next video!

Types of Plants 

There are many different types of plants.
There are trees, bushes, flowers, grasses and more!
Each one is unique in its own way.

Watch different flowers grow in the next video!

How do Flowers Reproduce? 

Bees and birds spread the flowers' pollen.
(the orange/yellow powder)

When the pollen is spread, the flowers will develop seeds!

Look for the pollen in flowers outside if you can!

What did you learn about plants today?

Name some plants near you.

Plant a seed in the ground, and try to grow it.

Take care of your plant. Look at it every day.

Draw pictures of it as it grows!

What is an animal?
What is your favorite animal?

Animals Need Food to Grow 

Just as we need food, animals need food too.
But, the food that they eat can be different
from the food that we eat.

You will now see some pictures of different animals.

Can you name these animals?

What do these animals eat to grow?

Animals Grow As They Get Older 

Animals start small when they are born,
and over time they grow and change, just like you!

The following pictures show how some animals change
as they grow.

Have you seen these animals grow?

How a Frog Grows 

The next picture shows how a frog grows.

It starts as an egg.

It then grows to a tadpole and swims like a fish.

Then it develops legs.

Finally, it becomes a frog!

How a Butterfly Grows 

The next picture shows how a butterfly grows.

Have you ever seen a butterfly?

It starts as an egg, becomes a larva (a caterpillar),
then it changes to a pupa (which is how a larva
gets ready to change into a butterfly).

Finally, it becomes a butterfly.

Reflection 

What happens to an animal as they get older?
What do animals need to grow?
How do you help animals so they can grow?

Name some animals you've seen grow!

Do they grow fast? Or slowly?

Draw pictures of animals you know and grow.

Class 4 Math: Geometry 
 Angles 

What do you already know about angles? 
How would you describe an angle? 
What do you think it measures?
What kinds of angles are there?

How to Make a Protractor 

1. Draw a circle on a paper going around a cup or bowl. 
2.  Cut it out.    Fold into half.   Fold it into half again.  
3. Unfold and mark the center. Cut into two half-circles.  
4. Look at picture of protractor and make yours the same.  
5. Divide each quarter into 9 equal parts. Label by 10 degrees. 
6. Mark 10 lines between each section- these are degrees!

FINAL Activities on Angles 

With a partner:

Describe different types of angles and how to measure them.

Describe different types of angles and how to measure them.
Find angles in the classroom. Guess their measurements.
Check them! 
Write an exercise to measure angles for your classmates.
Write an exam question about angles. 
See if your teacher uses it!

Introduction to Class 5 Science 
 Clouds 

Have you looked carefully at clouds?

Have they been the same shape or different?

What do you think causes the different shapes?

What are clouds made of?

Types of Clouds 

Cirrus: These remain at the top of the sky.They are white,
thin, curly, and usually contain more ice than water.
Cumulus: These are white and thick. Their upper part looks 
white like a cauliflower. The lower part looks black. 
These clouds contain a large amount of water.
Stratus: These clouds are spread in thin layers in the sky.
They look like fog when very thin stratus is near the ground.
Nimbus: Nimbus are dark brown and thick. They are found 
at a lower height than other clouds. Their shape is not fixed.
The steam is found at the lower part of this cloud.

Review 

Why are clouds important? 
Discuss with your partner and share with the class.

 How are clouds are made? Look at the diagram.
What are questions you have about clouds?

Write 2 questions with your partner. See if you can answer them.
Share your questions with your class.

Activity 

Go out and observe the sky. 
Are there clouds? What kinds are they? 

Make a "cloud section" in your copybook. 
Draw and label clouds today. Continue for about 10 days.
Make a prediction about the weather each day.
.What is the most common type of cloud you drew?
Were you able to predict the weather based on the clouds?

Class 5 Science 
Change of State of Matter 

     What is the difference between ice, water, and steam?

     What are the three states of matter?

     Do you think matter can change to another state of matter?

     Can you give some examples?

Describe the different states of matter
in the next picture.

States of Matter 

There are three states of matter:
1. Solid (ice)   2. Liquid (water)  3. Gas (steam)

When we transfer heat energy to ice, it becomes water.
When we transfer heat energy to water, it becomes steam.

Heating Solids 

Can you change other solid matter to liquid by heating it?
Yes! But you may need more heat than to melt ice!

Watch the next video about glass to learn more.
Then read about iron, also a solid that can be changed to liquid.
Take notes about what you learn. 

What new questions do you have?

Iron Becomes Liquid 

To extract iron ore: Steps:

 1. Mining the Iron Ore: Iron ore is a type of rock that contains

     iron. First, miners dig up the iron ore from the ground. They

     usually find it deep under the surface in big chunks of rock.

2. Crushing the Iron Ore: Once the iron ore is mined, it is crushed

     into smaller pieces to make it easier to process. This helps 

     separate the iron from the rest of the rock.

 3. Concentrating the Iron Ore: The small pieces of crushed iron

    ore are then put through a process that separates the iron from the other minerals in the rock. This is done using machines that can attract the iron particles and leave the rest behind. This step makes the iron ore more concentrated.

  1. Smelting the Iron Ore: The concentrated iron ore is mixed with a substance called coke (which is a type of coal) and heated in a furnace. This process is called smelting. When the iron ore and coke are heated to very high temperatures, the iron ore melts, and the iron is separated from other unwanted materials.

  2. Making the Useful Iron: The melted iron, called molten iron, is then poured into molds to cool and harden. Sometimes, the iron is mixed with other materials to make steel, which is a stronger type of iron used in buildings, cars, and many other things.

So, the main idea is to take iron ore from the ground, separate the iron from the rocks, and then melt it down to make useful iron products.

Iron Becomes Liquid (continued) 

To extract iron ore: Steps:

is then poured into molds to cool and harden. Sometimes, the 

iron is mixed with other materials to make steel, which is a 

stronger type of iron used in buildings, cars, and many other things.


So, the main idea is to take iron ore from the ground, separate 

the iron from the rocks, and then melt it down to make useful iron

products.

Changes in States of Matter 

melting = the change of solid state into liquid state by heating

freezing = the change of liquid state  into solid state by cooling

sublimation = process of converting solid directly into vapor by heat

evaporation = the change of liquid state into gas state by heating

condensation = the change of gas state into liquid state by cooling

Final Ideas and Experiment 

 Discuss and do with your partner:
What examples can you give of solids, liquids, and gas?
Write a list for each.
Give examples of turning something that is one state of matter 
to another.
Explain in writing.
Think of an experiment to change one form of matter to another.
Write down the materials, steps, and your hypothesis for results.
Draw pictures and write about each step.
Were the results what you expected?

Introduction to Class 5 Science 
 Exercise, Rest and Sleep 

Do you ever feel tired during the day?

(uncomfortable) when you wake up?

Balance is Key! 

It's important that you don't exercise 
or sleep too much or too little! 

On average, kids your age need at least 8 hours of sleep
and at least 1 hour of exercise every day!

Aerobic Exercise 

Aerobic exercise is any type of exercise that gets
the heart pumping and makes you breathe faster.

These type of exercises are good for your heart!

Class 5 Science: 
 Effects of Human Activities on the Environment 

Lesson Objectives

1. Determine if the world is warming or cooling.
2. Describe the 5 ways humans affect the environment.
3. Use words that describe how human beings and the environment 
   interact.

Pre-Quiz: 

Discuss with the class your ideas for the following:

   1. Do you think humans hurt or help the environment?

   2. Is the Earth getting colder or hotter?

   3. What kinds of pollution are harmful?

Look at the next slide and  decide if you are correct.
Based on what you just saw, is the Earth getting colder or warmer?

Is the Earth getting colder or warmer?

The Earth has been steadily getting warmer.
Do you think human beings help or hurt the environment?

Do human beings help or hurt the environment?

Answer: Many human activities hurt the environment.

 Actions such as: driving vehicles, putting garbage into bodies of 
 water, using pesticides, and burning forests worsen the air, 
 water, soil and forests all around us.

What kinds of pollution are harmful? 

1) Polluting the air
2) Polluting the water
3) Polluting the soil

For example: Human activities such as bathing
defecating, and putting garbage and chemicals in water
pollute the water (make it dirty).

Videos about Pollution 

Watch these two videos about plastics and pesticides.

What are the problems?
Why did these problems begin? 
Who or what are the causes?
What are solutions?

Why is it important to try to stop pollution of all sorts?

Discussion 


What do you think will happen
if we continue to hurt the environment?

Reflection 


Discuss: What do you see people around
you doing that hurts the environment?

What do you do that hurts the environment?

You Can Help! 

You can help stop pollution and climate change.
How?   Here are a few ideas:

Pick up trash
Walk places instead of driving.
Don't bathe in bodies of water (streams and lakes).
Plant a tree and protect it.
Turn off lights when you leave the room.
Practice other activities in your textbook.

Reflection 


Write down one thing you are going to do in the future
to help the environment.

Class 5 Science: Earth
Opener

What is the Earth made of?

What does the Earth's surface look like? Why?

What types of land forms can you think of on Earth's surface?

What types of water forms can you think of on Earth's surface?

Exploration

What do you think is at the center of the earth?

What do you think the center of the earth is made out of?

Vocabulary 

Crust: Outermost layer of the earth, made of rocks and soil

Mantle: Layer between crust and outside core, 
made of silicates (a type of salt)

Core: Innermost layer of the earth, divided into two parts:
1. Outer Core: made of  iron and nickel in molten state
2. Inner Core: made of solid iron and nickel 
(due to high pressure in the inner core)

Exploration

What causes changes to the Earth's surface?

Following is an example of soil erosion.

Soil erosion is the wearing away of the top layer of soil due to 
factors such as water, wind, or farming.

The surface of the Earth is also 
impacted by soil deposition.

Soil deposition is the process when soil or rocks 
are added to a landform or mass, due to 
factors such as wind and water.

Review 

Give some examples of landforms.

Describe soil erosion and soil deposition 
and how they change the surface of the Earth.

* The Sun accounts for 99.86% 
of all mass in the Solar System
* Over one million Earths can fit in the Sun!
* It takes 8 minutes for the Sun's light to reach Earth.

Planet #1: Mercury 

Mercury is the planet closest to the Sun.

Fun facts about Mercury:

* Mercury is the smallest planet in the solar system!
* Mercury the second hottest planet.
* Mercury does not have any moons!

Planet #2: Venus 

Venus is the 2nd closest planet to the Sun.

* Fun Facts about Venus:
* Venus is roughly the same size as Earth.
* Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system.
* Venus is the second brightest object in the night sky,
after the moon.

Planet #3: Earth 

Earth is the 3rd closest planet to the Sun.

Fun Facts about Earth:
We live on Earth, so it is our responsibility
to keep it clean!
Earth is the densest planet in the solar system.
Our planet may be the only to sustain life

The Moon 

The Moon is the Earth's natural satellite; it revolves around Earth
but is not a planet.

Fun Facts about the Moon:
* The Moon is the brightest object in our night sky.
* The light we see from moonlight 
is from the moon reflecting the Sun's rays.
* The Moon was first visited in 1969.

Planet #4: Mars 

Mars is the 4th closest planet to the Sun.

Fun Facts about Mars:
Mars is also called the Red Planet.
There are signs of liquid water on Mars.
We are currently planning expeditions 
to possibly land a human on Mars!
Mars has immense dust storms on its surface.

Planet #5: Jupiter 

Jupiter is the 5th closest planet to the Sun.

* Fun Facts about Jupiter:
* Jupiter has more than 60 moons!
* Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system.
* Jupiter is one of the gas giants,
meaning it is mostly comprised of gas.

Planet #6: Saturn 

Saturn is the 6th closest planet to the Sun.

Fun Facts about Saturn:
* Saturn is one of the gas giants
* Saturn's rings are composed of 
ice, rock, and dusts that may be from former planets
* Saturn has over 150 moons!
* Titan, one of Saturn's moons, may be able to sustain life.

Planet #7: Uranus 

Uranus is the 7th closest planet to the Sun.

Fun Facts about Uranus:
* Uranus is also called the "ice giant" planet 
due to its distinctive blue color.
* Uranus is the coldest planet in the solar system!
* Uranus was the 1st planet to be "discovered".

Planet #8: Neptune 

Neptune is the 8th closest planet to the Sun

Fun Facts about Neptune:
* Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun
* On average, Neptune is the coldest planet
(although Uranus can get even colder)
* Neptune has very violent storms, 
with winds reaching up to 600 meters per second

Review 

Our solar system has eight total planets- 
can you name them in order?

The general trend for planet temperature is as follows: 
the farther you are from the sun, the lower 
the average temperature.

Activity: in your copybooks, write a paragraph 
describing your favorite planet, and explain.

Class 5 Science: Plant Parts 

Go look at a plant!
What are the main parts of a plant?
Can you name five parts?
Do all plants have the same five parts?
Do all plants have flowers or fruit?

Plant Part #1: Root 

root: the part of the plant that is underground. 

What is the main function of a plant's roots?

A plant's root mainly helps draw nutrients
from the ground and fixes the plant to the soil.

Why do you think roots are so important?

Plant Part #2: Stem 

stem: the part of the plant above the ground
that the leaves and flowers are attached to

What is the main function of a plant stem?
A plant's stem supports the plant 
and allows for nutrients to be transferred.

The stem is like our backbones!

Plant Part #3: Leaf 

leaf: the part of the plant that produces
a plant's food using photosynthesis

photosynthesis: the process by which plants use sunlight
to convert carbon dioxide and water into food

What human body part do you think is similar to leaves?

Plant Part #4: Flower 

flower: the part of the plant that produces fruit and seed.
Flowers are usually colored!

Flowers produce the seeds that are
necessary for reproduction.

Activity: go outside and observe some flowers
in the garden, and comment on the color and size!

Some plants do not have flowers!
These are called non-flowering plants.
Trees are non-flowering plants.

The next two pictures will show plants that only have root,
stem, and leaves. These plants produce seeds 
in a different way.

Do you like flowering or non-flowering plants better?
Discuss with a partner.

Review 

What are the four main parts of a plant?

Review 

What are the four main parts of a plant?

They are: the root, stem, leaves, and flowers.

Activity: in your copybooks,
draw a picture of a flowering plant.

Be as creative as you want!

Introduction to Class 5 Science 
 Technology 

technology: the use of knowledge 
to invent new devices or tools

Can you name some examples of technology in the room 
right now? (hint: how are you viewing this right now?)

What are some examples of technology you use in the house?

Lamp 

Lamps use lightbulbs to provide light
for a room in an easy and efficient manner.

Lamps consist of a light bulb which provides a light
and a lamp shade which evenly distributes the light.

With your partner, discuss uses for lamps 
in your everyday life.

Light Bulb 

A light bulb is a kind of technology 
that gives us light in rooms!

Light bulbs use electricity to operate.
A lot of technologies also use electricity.

What are some common uses for light bulbs?

Flashlight 

Flashlights provide for us a portable source of light.

Flashlights rely on batteries for power.

Have you ever used a flashlight before? 

If so, when? If not, describe how it may be used.

Batteries 

Batteries give us a power source 
so we can operate hand-held items easily.

Batteries can be found in flashlights, 
smart phones, and a lot of different devices.

How have you used a battery before?

Reflection/ Activity

Do you have more questions?
Do you have resources to help you find answers?
Is there someone you can ask who might have an answer?

Look at home and around your community for examples 
of lots of different types of technology.
Make a class list. How many can you find?

It is important to compost organic wastes. By composting,

which helps plants grow.

that explain composting.

about how composting is important.

Managing Inorganic Wastes 

It is important to recycle inorganic wastes, 
such as iron, plastic, and glass.

of recycling and the importance
of reducing the amount of waste we produce.

Review

Ways We Can Prevent Malnutrition 

Make sure you do not wash the rice too thoroughly.

Class 4: Oviparous and Viviparous Animals 

Reproduction is an important part of life.
If animals or humans did not reproduce,
there would be no more life on Earth.
Some animals reproduce in different ways.
Can you think of different kinds of young?
(hint: think of butterflies versus dogs)

Review 

       Oviparous: animals that reproduce young by laying eggs

       Viviparous: animals that develop young in the womb
                    and nurse their young with milk

In the next few slides, identify each animal
as oviparous or viviparous.

Questions 

       Did you know the names of the animals?
       Have you seen insects or birds like ones in the pictures? 
       Are they viviparous or oviparous?

       Have you seen any of their eggs or their babies? Which ones?
       Have you seen mammals with their young? Which ones?

This one is a little bit harder!

1. What is the name of this animal?

2. Is it viviparous or oviparous?

Answers:

            1. This animal is called a platypus!

            2. This Australian animal is very special.
                It nurses its young with milk like other mammals, 
                but its young are born via eggs!

Reflection 

In general, mammals are usually viviparous,
and reptiles, birds, and insects are oviparous.

Grade 3 Math Multiplication

Practice Problems 

Let's practice...
What is 2 * 11
What is 12 * 4
What is 78 * 22
What is 98 * 41
What is 435 * 23
What is 319 * 65
Let's learn more about word problems

Word Problems 

There are 123 chocolates in a packet.
 How many chocolates are there in 24 packets?


There are 35 students in a line.
How many students are there in 12 lines?

Answers 

2 * 11 = 22, 12 * 4 = 48, 78 * 22 = 1,716
98 * 41 = 4,018, 435 * 23 = 10,005, 319 * 65 = 20,735

1. 2,952 packets of chocolate
2. 420 students in the 12 lines

Class 10 Math: Sets 

Remember sets?
What are sets? Give some examples.

How did we analyze them?
How can we compare sets?
How did we visualize sets?

Before we start, talk with a partner about the notation for sets.

Sets Introductory Discussion Answers 

A set is a collection of distinct objects.
We analyze sets by looking at the differences in the sets and the 
intersections between sets.

We compare sets by looking at either what numbers are contained 
in the sets, or by looking at how many terms are in the set.

We visualize sets using Venn diagrams.

ePaath Lesson Introduction 

In this ePaath lesson we will review sets and Venn diagrams.

Then we will learn about differences and complements.

What is a universal set? What would a different Venn diagram 
look like? 
What about a complement? What would a symmetrical difference 
Venn diagram look like? What's a cardinal number?

Discuss with a partner before we start

ePaath Lesson Introduction Answers 

A universal set is the set of all possible values (ex. {a,b,c,d,e,f}).

A difference Venn diagram for A and B would mean that only A 
would be shaded and the region that's shared between A and B 
wouldn't.

A symmetrical difference Venn diagram would mean A and B would
both be shaded but not the region between.

A cardinal number is the quantity of a number rather than the 
order in a set

Sets Example Problem 1 

In a school of 400 children, 240 students take an art class and
210 students take a music class. 377 students take either an art 
class or a music class. How many students take both classes?

Name the rule that you must use to solve this problem.

Visualize the problem by drawing a Venn diagram in your copybook.

Solve the problem and compare answers with a partner.

Sets Example Problem 1 
Answers

In a school of 400 children, 240 students take an art class and
210 students take a music class. 377 students take either an art 
class or a music class. How many students take both classes?

n(AUB) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A or B)
x = 240 + 210 - 377
x = 73
73 students take both classes.

Sets Example Problem 2 

A survey was conducted of Looma students. In the survey, 68% of
 students liked playing football, 22% of students liked baseball, and
5% of students like another sport the most. What percentage of 
students like both? If 15 students liked a sport besides baseball 
or football, how many students were surveyed?

Draw a Venn diagram showing the results of the students surveyed.

Sets Example Problem 2 
Answers

A survey was conducted of Looma students. In the survey, 68% of
students liked playing football, 22% of students liked baseball, and
 5% of students like another sport the most. What percentage of 
students like both baseball and football? If 15 students liked a 
sport besides baseball or football, how many students 
were surveyed?

68% + 22% + 5% = 95%, so 5% of students like both
15/x = 5/100, x = 300

Example Problem 3 

Set A: {3, 5, 2, 7}
Set B: {1, 2, 6, 9, 12, 13, 5}
Set C: {3, 5, 2, 6, 11, 10}


a) n(A) + n(B) + n(C) = ?
b) n(A) - n(B intersection C) + n(C symmetrical difference A) = ?

Example Problem 3 Answers 

Set A: {3, 5, 2, 7}
Set B: {1, 2, 6, 9, 12, 13, 5}
Set C: {3, 5, 2, 6, 11, 10}

a) n(A) + n(B) + n(C) = 4 + 7 + 6 = 17
b) n(A) - n(B intersection C) + n(C symmetrical difference A) = 
4 - 2 + 4 = 6

Review and Challenge 

Did you learn notation for sets?
Did you learn what the intersections and differences are for sets?

Remember!
 If A and B are two disjoint subsets of universal set U, 
 then n(A union B) = n(A) + n(B)
If A and B are two intersecting subsets of universal set U, then 
 n(A union B) = n(A) + n(B) – n(A not B)

Now you try to make up your own problem and have a partner solve it!

Grade 8 Science: Measurement 

What is Measurement?
Measurement is the process of finding the size,
length or amount of any quantity.

Answer the following questions with a partner or small group: 
1. What are some things we measure?
2. How do we measure these things?
3. Why is being able to have measurements important?

ePaath Activity 

Complete the following ePaath activity about SI Measurements. 

Write down any questions you have as you go along.

Questions Q

Answer the following questions with your partner:

1. What are the types of physical quantities? 

2. What are some examples of fundamental quantities?

3. What are some examples of derived quantities?

Answers  

1. What are the types of physical quantities?
There are two types: fundamental and derived quantities.

2. What are some examples of fundamental quntities?
Some fundamental quantities are length, time, mass, etc.

3. What are some examples of derived quantities?
 Some derived quantities are area, pressure, weight, etc.

Mass vs. Weight 

Now, let's go over the difference between mass and weight. 

Watch the following video. Before you start watching the video,
look at the five statements. 
Write down if each statement is true or false.

 Once everyone is done, continue watching and check your answers.

q Mass vs. Weight Questions 

Review your answers to the previous statements.

If you answered a statement incorrectly, which part of your
 reasoning led you to the wrong answer? 

What is the difference between mass and weight? 

Which one is a fundamental quantity, and which one is
a derived quantity?

Mass vs. Weight Answers 

What is the difference between mass and weight? 
Mass is a measurement of the amount of matter an object contains.
Weight is a measurement of the force of gravity on an object.
 
Which one is a fundamental quantity, and which one is a derived
quantity?
Mass is a fundamental quantity, it is measured in grams.
Weight is a derived quantity because it depends on the force of 
gravity on an object AND an object's mass; 
it is measured in newtons or kg*m*s^(-2).

you've learned.

Whoever guessed the closest measurement wins!

Grade 8 Science: Velocity and Acceleration 

Work with a partner or small group. 
See if you can come up with a definition for the following: 

1. What is Velocity? 

2. What is Acceleration?

Textbook 


Read your textbook about Velocity and Acceleration. 
As you read, notice how your definitions of Velocity and 
Acceleration compare to the textbook definitions.

Textbook Reflection 

Textbook definitions:
Velocity is the speed of something in a particular direction. (m/s)
Acceleration is the change in velocity per unit time. (m/s^2)

  How did your definitions of Velocity and Acceleration differ 
  from the textbook? 

  Which aspects of your reasoning were right? 
  Which ones were wrong? Why?

Review of equations: velocity and acceleration 

To find velocity: 
v = s/t
where s = distance, t = time

To find acceleration: 
a = (v - u)/t
where u = initial velocity, v = final velocity

Relative Velocity 

What is relative velocity? 

Watch the next video of Dr. Dann's experiment.
Listen carefully to why the ball lands in the accelerated cart.

Review: Relative Velocity 

Relative Velocity is the velocity of a body described with respect
to a reference point.  

The ball and the cart have the same horizontal speed, so even if
the ball is going up, it's moving forward at the same amount of 
time. 

If the cart is accelerating, the ball will still go inside the cart 
because when the ball landed, the cart was at a lower height, so the ball
spent more time in the air, which also had more time to move forward.

ePaath Activity 


Complete the following ePaath activity about velocity, acceleration, 
and useful equations. Remember these, they will be useful later!

Let's Review the Equations! 

On the following slides, copy down the 4 main equations. Notice 
how each one can be modified to solve for different variables.

Equation 1 

a = (v-u)/t

try modifying for different variables:
a = (v-u)/t
at = v-u
t = (v-u)/a OR v = u + at OR u = v - at


(where a = acceleration, u = intitial velocity, v = final velocity,
 t = time, s = distance travelled)

Equation 2 

s = (v+u)t / 2

try modifying for different variables:
s = (v+u)t / 2
2s = (v+u)t
t = 2s/(v+u)

(where a = acceleration, u = intitial velocity, v = final velocity,
 t = time, s = distance travelled)

Equation 3 

s = ut + 1/2at^2

This is a hard one! 
Equation 3 is best used only solving for s. 


(where a = acceleration, u = intitial velocity, v = final velocity,
 t = time, s = distance travelled)

Equation 4 

v^2 = u^2 + 2as

try modifying for other variables:
 v^2 = u^2 + 2as
u^2 = v^2 - 2as OR 2as = v^2 - u^2

(where a = acceleration, u = intitial velocity, v = final velocity,
 t = time, s = distance travelled)

Let's Do Some Practice Problems! 

Try to use your notes to answer the questions on the following 
slides.
(Hint: Use the equations we just learned!)

(Don't forget! a = acceleration, u = initial velocity, 
v = final velocity, t = time, s = distance travelled)

B) Pick an equation that uses the variables in the question.
 Equation 4, v^2 = u^2 + 2as, is a good choice for this problem. 
v^2 = (2m/s)^2 + 2 * 2.5m/s^2 * 12m

(Don't forget! a = acceleration, u = initial velocity,

Summary (Definitions) 

Velocity: rate of change of distance in a particular direction (m/s)
Relative Velocity: the velocity of an object described with respect
to a reference point

 Acceleration: the change in velocity per unit time (m/s^2)
If the velocity of an object increases, then the object is moving 
with a positive acceleration.
If the velocity of an object decreases, then the object is moving 
with a negative acceleration (retardation).
 If the velocity of an object remains constant, then the object is moving with
a zero acceleration

Summary (Equations) 

(where a = acceleration, u = initial velocity, v = final velocity,
 t = time, s = distance travelled)

          velocity:    v = s / t 
          equation 1: a = (v - u) / t 
          equation 2: s = ( v + u ) * t / 2
          equation 3: s = ut + 1/2at^2
          equation 4: v^2 = u^2 + 2as

Grade 4 Math 
 Concept of Numbers 
 Rounding off Numbers 

What is rounding?

Why do we need to use rounding in our daily lives?

How do you round numbers to the nearest ten?

How do you round numbers to the nearest hundred?

Vocabulary Review 

Rounding is making a number simpler by changing it to the
nearest number ending with a 0. Your teacher will specify
if they want you to round a number to the nearest ten, so
that the number in the tens place is a 0, or if they want 
you to round to the nearest hundred, so both the tens 
place and the hundreds place have a 0. When rounding 
tens, anything less than 5 in the ones place means that 
the number is rounded down. If the number in the ones 
place is a 5 or higher, the number is rounded up.

Vocabulary Review 

Prime numbers are numbers that are only divisible by 
1 and themselves. For example, 7 is a prime number. It
can only be divided by 1 to get 7 or divided by 7 to get 1.
It cannot be divided into a whole number by any other number. 

Composite numbers are numbers that are divisible by one,
themselves, and another number. For example, 10 can be
divided by 1 to get 10 and divided by 10 to get 1, but it can
also be divided by 5 to get 2 and divided by 2 to get 5.

ePaath Lesson: Rounding Numbers

Grade 8 Science: Simple Machine 

What are simple machines and what do they do?

What are levers and how do they work?

How do the forces of effort and load 
and their distances from the fulcrum interact?

Introduction 

The following vocabulary is related to this subject:

simple machine      lever      fulcrum      effort      load
load distance    arm distance    load arm    effort arm
mechanical advantage          velocity ratio
 input work      output work
efficiency         newton (N)

Vocabulary Review 

A simple machine is something we use to make our work
easier, faster, and simpler. Simple machines can lift heavy
loads with a small force. They make doing work a faster process
and they can change the direction of the applied force.

A lever is a long bar or plank that can rotate around a fulcrum.

A fulcrum is a fixed point or pivot.

Vocabulary Review 

Load is the force working against effort, like how
a weight on a scientific scale weighs down one side of the scale.

Effort is the force working against the load, like how
the counterweight on a scientific scale balances the sides of the scale.

Load distance is the distance between the load and the fulcrum.

Effort distance is the distance between the effort and the fulcrum.

Vocabulary Review 

Load arm and effort arm are the sections of lever between the
load and the fulcrum and the effort and the fulcrum, respectively.

**Important Concept: Principle of Lever**
effort x effort distance = load x load distance

This essentially means that the effort and load forces are 
multiplied by their respective distances from the fulcrum, and we 
can conclude that if the effort or load is farther away from the
fulcrum, the force will be bigger.

Vocabulary Review 

   Mechanical advantage or MA is the ratio of load to effort on
   a balanced lever (MA = L/E) or the number of times the force 
   of effort is multiplied by the machine.

   Velocity ratio or VR is the ratio of the output work to the input 
   work.
                       (VR = output work/input work)

Vocabulary Review 

   Input work is the work done by the effort 
(effort x effort distance)

   Output work is work done by the machine to move the load 
(load x load distance)

 Efficiency is the ratio of output work to input work in a machine
  (Efficiency = output/input) and it also algebraically can be turned
 into the ratio of the mechanical advantage to the velocity ratio
 (E = MA/VR)

Vocabulary Review 

newton (N): the international unit of measure for force. One
             newton is equal to one kilogram meter per second 
             squared. 
N = 1 kg (m/s2)

ePaath Lesson: Levers 

Complete the following lesson. 
Do all activities.

Learn more about levers work and review vocabulary learned in this
 lesson such as mechanical advantage and efficiency.

Practice Problem Set 

Complete the following practice problems to solidify 
your understanding of simple machine concepts

#1: An effort of 50 N is 2 cm away from the fulcrum on a lever.
If the load is 5 cm away, what is its mass?



(Hint: effort x effort distance = load x load distance)

Answer to Practice Problem #1 

#1: An effort of 50 N is 2 cm away from the fulcrum on a lever.
If the load is 5 cm away, what is its mass?

Answer: 10 N

I algebraically solved for the load by dividing the product of the 
effort and effort distance by the load distance to get the mass of
the load.

(Hint: effort x effort distance = load x load distance)

Practice Problem Set 

#2: A load of 500 N is being lifted by an effort of 20 N.
What is the lever's mechanical advantage? (MA)






(Hint: mechanical advantage = load/effort)

Practice Problem Set 

#2: A load of 500 N is being lifted by an effort of 20 N.
What is the lever's mechanical advantage? (MA)

Answer: 25

I divided the load of 500 N by the effort of 20 N to get the 
mechanical advantage. There are no units because the 
Newtons (N) cancel.

(Hint: mechanical advantage = load/effort)

Practice Problem Set 

#3: Lever A has a velocity ratio of 4. The load is 10 cm away
from the fulcrum. What is the effort distance?






(Hint: velocity ratio = effort distance/load distance)

Answer to Practice Problem #3 

#3: Lever A has a velocity ratio of 4. The load is 10 cm away
from the fulcrum. What is the effort distance?

Answer: 40 cm

I algebraically solved for the effort distance in the equation below
 by multiplying velocity ratio by the load distance to get the effort
 distance.

(Hint: velocity ratio = effort distance/load distance)

Practice Problem Set 

#4: Lever A from the previous problem (go back to the previous
 slide) has an efficiency rating of 5. What is its mechanical 
advantage?




(Hint: η=MA/VR)

Answer to Practice Problem #4 

#4: Lever A from the previous problem (go back to the previous 
slide) has an efficiency rating of 5. What is its mechanical 
advantage?
Answer: 20

I solved for the mechanical advantage algebraically by dividing 
the efficiency (η) by the velocity ratio (see previous slide).

(Hint: η=MA/VR)

Intro. to Lesson: Grade 5, Math, Chapter 3, Fundamental Operations in 
 Mathematics 

Big Ideas: 
- Mathematical Operations: Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication, Division
- Parenthesis, Braces, and Brackets
- Order of Operations
- Simplification
Guiding Questions:
How do you simplify using mathematical operations?
How does the order of operations affect simplification?

Before Reading Sections 1 & 2 in Chapter 3 

The following resource will tell you about mathematic operations, brackets,
and the order of operations.

Take notes about what it means to simplify and how you simplify.

Video 


Watch the following video on the history and usefulness of math symbols


While watching, think about why symbols are used and 
why they can be helpful.

After Video 

After watching the video, discuss what adding a variable does to an equation

When a variable is combined with a number (2x for example), 
what is the relationship between them?

The number (coefficient) is multiplied by the variable

Mathematical Operations 

The four fundamental mathematical operations are:
- Addition (+)
- Subtraction (-)
- Multiplication (x)
- Division (÷)

Which operations come first? 
What is simplification?

Answers about Order of Operations 

First, you compute all division (÷) or multiplication (x).
Next, you compute all addition (+) or subtraction (-). 
This order is called the order of operations.

The act of doing these operations is called simplification.

Fundamental Operations: Activities and Discussion 

Do exercise 1 & 2 on page 35 of the textbook.

Fundamental Operations Practice 

Simplify the following expressions:
15 ÷ 5 x 3 + 7 - 15

55 - 576 ÷ 12 + 11 x 3

Fundamental Operations Practice Answers 

15 ÷ 5 x 3 + 7 - 15
= 3 x 3 + 7 – 15 
= 9 + 7 – 15  
= 16 – 15
= 1 
55 - 576 ÷ 12 + 11 x 3
= 55 - 48 + 11 x 3 
= 55 - 48 + 33  
= 7 + 33
= 40

Parentheses, Braces, and Brackets 

Parentheses (), Braces {}, and Brackets [] come first in the order of 
operations

They are used to create groups to simplify a problem

What happens if there are parentheses inside of brackets? What comes first?

When there are multiple parentheses, braces, or brackets, the one that is
inside always comes first

Parentheses, Brackets, and Braces practice 

Simplify the following expressions:

6 + ( 5 x 4 ) -1

12 - ( 4 + [ 3 x 7 ] ) + 5

Parentheses, Brackets, and Braces Practice Answers 

6 + ( 5 x 4 ) - 1
= 6 + ( 20 ) - 1
= 26 - 1
= 25

12 - ( 4 + [ 3 x 7 ] ) + 5
= 12 - ( 4 + [ 21 ] ) + 5
= 12 - ( 25 ) + 5
= -13 + 5
= -8

Grade 4 Science: 
 Vertebrate and Invertebrate Animals 

A vertebrate is an animal that has a backbone.
An invertebrate is an animal that does not have a backbone.

What kinds of vertebrate animals do you see in your 
everyday life? What about invertebrate animals?

Review 

Vertebrate animals are strong because they have bones 
inside their body, while invertebrate animals are soft because they
don't have any bones. 

Animals like mammals, reptiles, and fish are vertebrates.
Animals like insects and microorganisms and bacteria are
invertebrates.
Bones in our body help shape and support the body, allowing 
us to stand upright and have a height.

Activity: Vertebrate or Invertebrate?

are small and do not have bones.

Before ePaath

few questions:

    2) What about the characteristics of invertebrate animals? 
    3) What are things that vertebrates can do that invertebrates
       can't?
Write your answers on a piece of paper.

After ePaath 

1) Vertebrate animals have a definite body shape, can stand 
straight, are made up of skin and bones, and their bodies
are strong. They can walk, fly, swim and burrow under the ground.

2) Invertebrate animals do not have bones, so their bodies are soft.
They tend to have small bodies and are made up of muscle. 
Invertebrates usually face downwards. 

3) Vertebrates can carry weight and can run or fly. Which 
vertebrate plows fields?

A Brief History of Numerical Systems Review 

We began counting objects in order to keep track of flocks and
tribe members.

to record larger numbers in more sophisticated ways.

What is a positional system?
What is the base ten system?

A Brief History of Numerical Systems Review
 Part 2 

What is a positional system?
A positional system means that the value of a digit
depends on its position in the entire number.

What is the base ten system?
The base ten system is a type of positional system where the
units place is counted by ones, the tens place is counted by tens,
the hundreds place is counted by hundreds, etc.

Before ePaath: The Number System

After ePaath: The Number System 

Natural numbers: We use these to count objects.
Whole numbers: We use these to count objects and also include 0.
Integers: We use these to count objects, include 0, and
include negative numbers. Example:Temperature, floors of a building
Rational numbers: We use these like integers, and also to use
  fractions. We use fractions to measure a part of a whole.

We can write down a set of numbers using set notation: 
N={1,2,3,...}
We can also use a number line.
Remind yourself: Is 0 a counting number?

After ePaath: The Number System 
 Part 2 

Remind yourself: Is 0 a counting number?
0 is NOT a counting number. Therefore, 0 is a whole number
but not a natural number.

Grade 6 Math 
 Highest Common Factor and Lowest Common Multiple 

Big Ideas
-Defining the Lowest Common Multiple (LCM) and
the Highest Common Factor (HCF).
-Learning how to find both HCF and LCM.

Guiding Questions
-How will prime factorization be used to help us?

Instruction 

Read about HCF (Highest Common Factor) and 
LCM (Lowest Common Multiple) as directed by your teacher.

Note how the HCF and the LCM are found from the sets.

Instruction: Highest Common Factor Explanation 

The HCF of two numbers is found by...
Finding the factors of the two numbers, isolating the 
factors that they both have (common factors), and finding the 
highest number among the common factors.

Example: 60 and 105
F(60) = {2, 2, 3, 5}, F(105) = {3, 5, 7}
Common Factors: 3, 5 Highest Common Factor: 3x5=15

Instruction 
 Lowest Common Multiple Explanation Part 1 

The LCM of two numbers is found by...
1) Listing multiples of each number until a common multiple
appears.
Example: LCM of 30 and 45
30: {30, 60, 90, ...}
45: {45, 90, ...}
This method is not efficient.
Turn to the next slide for the second method

Instruction: Lowest Common Multiple Explanation Part 2 

The LCM of two numbers is found by...
2) Take the prime factorization of each number and simplify
so the factors are in their highest exponent form. 
Then multiply the factors in their highest exponent form.
Example: LCM of 30 and 45
30 = 2 * 3 * 5
45 = 3^2 * 5
LCM = 2 * 3^2 * 5 = 90
This method is more efficient than the first method.

Instruction: Before Resource 

Now, a Khan Academy video will explain finding both 
Highest Common Factor and Lowest Common Multiple.

Look for different methods of finding the answers in
the video compared to the what you have read.

Instruction: After Resource 

Talk about the different methods used
in the video and in your reading.

Think about how LCM can be used in the real world.
(What examples did he use in the video?)

Exploration 
 HCF Practice 1 

What is the HCF of 63 and 81?

Exploration 
 HCF Practice 1 Answer 

What is the HCF of 63 and 81?
63 = 3^2 * 7
81 = 3^4

The HCF is 3^2 = 9.

Exploration 
 HCF Practice 2 

What is the HCF of 6 and 35?

Exploration 
 HCF Practice 2 Answer 

What is the HCF of 6 and 35?
6 = 2 * 3
35 = 5 * 7

6 and 35 have no common factors in the prime factorization.
The HCF of 6 and 35 is 1.

Exploration 
 LCM Practice 1 

What is the LCM of 6 and 16?

Exploration 
 LCM Practice 1 Answer 

What is the LCM of 6 and 16?
6 = 2 * 3
16 = 2^4

The LCM is 2^4 * 3 = 48.

Exploration 
 LCM Practice 2 

What is the LCM of 27 and 81?

Exploration 
 LCM Practice 2 Answer 

What is the LCM of 27 and 81?
27 = 3^3
81 = 3^4
The LCM is 3^4 = 81.

We can also solve this knowing that the LCM of one number
(like 27) and its multiple (81) is always the multiple.

Exploration 
 HCF and LCM Practice 1 

There are 44 strawberries and 28 bananas.
How many people can share all of the fruit with equal portions?
How big are each of the portions?

Exploration 
 HCF and LCM Practice 1 Answer 
There are 44 strawberries and 28 bananas.
How many people can share all of the fruit with equal portions?
How big are each of the portions?
This is an HCF problem.
44 = 2^2 * 11         28 = 2^2 * 4
The HCF is 2^2 = 4. 4 people can share all of the fruit.
Each person will receive 44 / 4 = 11 strawberries and
28 / 4 = 7 bananas.

Exploration 
 HCF and LCM Practice 2 

Bus A comes every 20 minutes and 
Bus B comes every 48 minutes.
They both arrive at 7AM.

When will both buses arrive next at the same time?

Exploration 
 HCF and LCM Practice 2 Answer 
Bus A comes every 20 minutes; Bus B comes every 48 minutes.
They both arrive at 7AM.
When will both buses arrive next at the same time?
This is an LCM problem.
20 = 2^2 * 5
48 = 2^4 * 3
The LCM is 2^4 * 3 * 5 = 240 minutes, or 4 hours.
They will both arrive at 11AM.

HCF and LCM Review 

The HCF is the highest common factor of some numbers.
We find the HCF by prime factorizing the numbers and then
finding the highest common factor.

The LCM is the lowest common multiple.
We find the LCM by prime factorizing the numbers and then
multiplying the factors in their highest exponent form.
We can also find the LCM by finding the multiples
of the numbers until we find a common multiple.

Grade 8 Science: Light 

Discuss with a partner or small group. 
Try to answer the following questions with reasoning:


1. Why can we see our surroundings during the day, but not at 
   night? 

2. Why can we see our reflection in a mirror, but not a piece of 
   wood?

Discussion 

1. Why can we see our surroundings during the day, but not at 
night? 

    Because of light! Light from the sun or another light source 
    reflects off of all of the objects around us. When these 
    reflected rays reach our eyes, that is what allows us to see 
    them.

Discussion 

2. Why can we see our reflection in a mirror, but not a piece of 
wood?

When you look very closely at the materials, a mirror is smooth, 
but wood is not. When light reflects off of a completely smooth 
surface, the light rays are reflected in a uniform manner, creating an image which we can see. This
is called specular reflection. When light reflects off of wood, 
the light rays go in random directions, which we cannot see! 
This is called diffuse reflection.

Textbook 


If your textbook has a chapter on Light, see if you can answer
the following questions: 

What is an image? What is the difference between convex and 
concave?

ePaath Activity 


Complete the following ePaath activity about Light.
Look out for the following vocabulary:

Law of Reflection, Image, Convex, Concave

Questions Q

Answer the following questions with a partner or small group:

1. What is the Law of Reflection of Light? 

2. What is the difference between convex and concave? 

3. Think of a mirror in your life. Is it a plane, a convex or a 
concave mirror? Explain how you got your answer.

Answers/Explanation Q

1. What is the Law of Reflection of Light? 

It states that when light is reflecting off of a surface, the 
incoming angle (incident ray) is always equal to the angle leaving 
the surface (reflected ray).

Answers/Explanation Q

2. What is the difference between convex and concave mirrors? 
Convex mirrors bulge outwards towards the light source and cause 
light rays to diverge (spread out). Concave mirrors cave inwards 
away from the light source and cause light rays to converge 
(meet at one point).

3. Think of a mirror in your life. Is it a plane, a convex or a 
concave mirror? 
See definitions for convex and concave above. Plane mirrors are 
flat.

ePaath Activity 


Complete the following ePaath Activity about Ray Diagrams.

Takes notes on how to draw a Ray Diagram so you can do it on 
your own.

Concave Mirrors Video 

Watch the following video but stop at 5:10 to see how Dr. Dann 
draws 2 ray diagrams for a concave mirror.

Should you place the object in front of or behind the focus if
 you want to create a virtual image? What about a real image?

Concave Mirrors Review 

Should you place the object in front of or behind the focus if
 you want to create a virtual image? What about a real image?

To form a...

Virtual image: place the object between the focus and mirror. 
Real image: place the object beyond the focus point.

Refraction 

So far, we have only talked about how light is reflected, meaning it
bounces off of the surface of a material.

But what happens when light goes through a material (also called a
medium)?

Refraction is when light goes through/between two mediums of 
different densities, causing it to bend.

Textbook 

If your textbook has a section on Refraction, read it and 
think about the following:

How is refraction similar to reflection? How are they different?

Refraction Video 


Watch the following video demonstrating how refraction works.
Notice how the light bends when it crosses between water and air.

Final Activity 

Work with a partner. 
Try to draw the ray diagram or sketch of an object for each of 
the following:

A) Reflection off of a plane mirror
  B) Reflection off of a concave mirror
C) Reflection off of a convex mirror
D) Refraction between air and water

Be sure to include the following when necessary: 
focus, center of curvature, principal axis, location of object, normal

Grade 10 Math: Tax and Money Exchange 

Objective:
After completing this chapter, students will understand
               -Discounts and Taxes
               -VAT (Value Added Tax) and Discounts
               -Money Exchange Rates

Opener:
               -How do we calculate the price after tax?
               -How do we convert currencies?

Profit and Loss 

-The price at which a store buys a product differs from
the price at which a store sells a product.
-The price at which a store buys a product is the
cost price or C.P.
-The price at which a store sells a product is the
selling price or S.P.

How does the difference between the C.P. and S.P. affect
the amount of money a store makes or loses?

Profit and Loss 

If the S.P. is greater than the C.P. and the expenses, the store
 makes more money than they spent. This extra money is called a
profit.
The amount of profit is equal to the S.P. - C.P. - expenses.

If the S.P. is lower than the C.P. + the other expenses, the store
 makes less money than they spent. This lost money is called a loss.
The amount of loss is equal to the C.P. - S.P. + expenses.
(The S.P. - C.P. is the Gross Margin, NOT the profit)

Profit and Loss (continued) 

We always want to increase profit and minimize loss ethically 
without, for example, lowering employees' wages.

How could we create a standardized value to compare 
profit and loss?

Profit and Loss 

One way to create a standardized value to compare profit and loss
is to use a profit/loss %.

The profit/loss % measures the size of the average profit
compared to the size of the average loss per trade.

The profit/loss % is equal to...
(net profit / loss) / cost * 100%

Intro to Tax 

In order for the government to function, it needs enough money.
How does the government raise money?

Intro to Tax 

The government raises money by levying a tax. A tax is the 
amount of money which the government requires people and 
companies to pay.

Taxes are used for security, welfare, education, health,
infrastructure, and other public concerns.

One type of tax is called income tax.
Based on the name, what do you think income tax is?

Income Tax 

Income tax is a type of tax which someone must pay based on 
their income.
         - Below a certain amount, income is not taxable.
         - This non-taxable amount is called the allowance.
         - Above this certain amount, income is taxable. This 
           amount is called the taxable amount.

Income Tax 

The range of incomes are divided into sections.
Your allowance and taxable amount depend on your income section.

Lower incomes have lower allowances and lower taxable amounts.
Higher incomes have higher allowances and higher taxable amounts.

Trade Discounts 

A trade discount is the allowance for selling goods to distributors.

Distributors are stores that sell goods directly to consumers.

For example, if a store is buying cans of soup from a company to 
sell to customers later, the trade discount is the discount that the
company will give to the store to buy them. The discounted price
is then taxed.

Discounts 

Have you ever purchased an item for a price that
was less than it was marked?
A discount is the lowering of the price for a good or service to
appeal to the customers more. Often, discounts are measured
by stating that a certain percentage of the marked price of an
item has been removed for the selling price.

For example, if an item costs Rs.1000 and there's a discount of 
15%, then the selling price of the item will be Rs.850 before tax.

Value Added Tax (VAT) 

The Value Added Tax is added on to the selling price of an item 
that a customer is buying.

The customer has to pay the combination of the selling price
AND the added tax.

VAT is measured in a percentage. For example, if the VAT is 13%
and an item is Rs. 100, then the cost that the customer will pay
is Rs. 113, because 100 + (13% x 100) = 100 + 13 = 113.

VAT Practice Problem Sheet 

What does the customer pay? (MP means Marked Price)

Marked Price,     Discount,       VAT
1) MP: Rs.1400, no discount, VAT: 15%

2) MP: Rs.1640, 25% discount, VAT: 10%

3) MP: Rs.4000, 5% discount, VAT: 20%

VAT Practice Problem Answers 
1) MP: Rs.1400, no discount, VAT: 15%
1) 1400 + (0.15 x 1400) = 1400 + 210 = Rs.1610
2) MP: Rs.1640, 25% discount, VAT: 10%
2) (1640 - (0.25 x 1640)) + (0.10 x (1640 - (0.25 x 1640)))
(1640 - 410) + (0.10 x (1640 - 410))
1230 + (0.10 x 1230) = 1230 + 123 = Rs.1353
3) MP: Rs.4000, 5% discount, VAT: 20%
3) (4000 - (0.05 x 4000)) + (0.20 x (4000 - (0.05 x 4000)))
(4000 - 200) + (0.20 x (4000 - 200)
3800 + (0.20 x 3800) = 3800 + 760 = Rs.4560

Exchange Rates 

Have you ever had to convert currency before?
What currency was it?

Exchange Rate Discussion 

If your textbook includes a chapter on exchange rates, read it and
see if you can answer the following question:

What is the exchange rate of currencies dependent on?

Money Exchange Practice 1 

An American man comes to Nepal. He wants to exchange
$6000 into Nepalese rupees. The broker will take a 2% commission.
Calculate the amount of rupees which the man will receive.

Money Exchange Practice 1 

   An American man comes to Nepal. He wants to exchange
   $6000 into Nepalese rupees. The broker will take a 2% 
   commission. Calculate the amount of money the man will receive.

The man is buying rupees. We use the buying rate.
$1 = Rs. 106.80 (buying rate)
$6000 = Rs. 6,40,800
2% of Rs. 6,40,800 = Rs. 12,816
6,40,800 - 12,816 = 6,27,984
The man will receive Rs. 6,27,984

Money Exchange Practice 2 

Deepak bought 700 Chinese Yuan. That afternoon, the Nepalese
Rupee increased in value by 10%. How much profit or loss
does Deepak receive if she exchanges her Yuan back to Rupees
that evening?

Money Exchange Practice 2 
Deepak bought 700 Chinese Yuan. That afternoon, the Nepalese
Rupee increased in value by 10%. How much profit or loss
does Deepak receive if she exchanges her Yuan back to Rupees
that evening?
We first find how many rupees she paid for the Chinese Yuan.
1 Chinese Yuan = Rs. 15.66 (selling rate)
700 Chinese Yuan = 700 * Rs. 15.66 = Rs. 10962
After the Rupee increases:
                 1 Chinese Yuan = Rs. 15.66 - 10% Rs. 15.66
                 1 Chinese Yuan = Rs. 14.094
                 700 Chinese Yuan = Rs. 9865.8
Profit = Rs. 10,962 - Rs. 9,865.8 = Rs. 1,096.2

Review 

We've learned about how: 
VAT adds on to the selling price. 
Discounts lower from the marked price.
Trade Discounts and Allowances affect how much taxes are paid.
Profit/Loss % is a standard way to measure the gains or losses.
Exchange Rates are different for different currencies.

The next time that you buy anything, look for any discounts on the
item and look for how much the taxes will add on to the cost.

Grade 4  Science: Aquatic Plants 

Aquatic plants are plants found in water. 

Have you seen any aquatic plants near your home? 
What are your favorite aquatic plants? 

As you learn about aquatic plants, think about the characteristics
of aquatic plants and their similarities and differences with
terrestrial plants.

About Aquatic Plants 

There are different types of aquatic plants. Some float on 
the surface of the water. These are called floating plants.
Some are completely submerged under
the water. These are called submergent plants.
And some have their roots in the water and their heads above the
water. These are called emergent plants.

Aquatic plants that float on the surface include lotus flowers, 
water hyacinth, and pistia (water lettuce). Their roots are fixed 
in the soil and their stems are below the surface; you can only see
the flowers and leaves on the surface.he inside water, get sunlight and survive there.

More About Aquatic Plants 


Plants that are completely underwater (submerged) include 
Hydrilla and Vallisneria.

 They take in carbon dioxide, get sunlight and grow under water.

Before ePaath 

Complete the ePaath lesson and exercise.
Pay attention to the different types of terrestrial and 
aquatic plants. 

What are the similarities between terrestrial plants 
and aquatic plants? 
What are some examples of each type of plants? 
Give two for each type.

After ePaath 

Let's review about terrestrial and aquatic plants.
Similarities:
They have different body parts with different functions.
Examples: root, stem, leaf, flower, and (sometimes) fruits
Differences:
Terrestrial plants are found on land, while aquatic plants
are found in water. Almost all aquatic plants are soft,
the roots are small and less developed, and have waxy stems
and leaves so they won't decay so easily.

Activity: Identify the Plant 


Starting from the next slide, there are going to be four photos 
of different plants. Your job is to figure out whether that plant is
terrestrial or aquatic and then say why using the characteristics 
you have learned about.

Summary 
     In this lesson, we learned about aquatic plants
     and their characteristics. We also learned about the
     differences and similarities of aquatic and terrestrial plants.
 
Think about these three questions: 
    1. What kind of plants found in rivers or ponds can you find 
        near your house or at school?
    2. What do aquatic plants and terrestrial plants need to 
        survive? 
    3. How do they get nutrients?

Saying the time 

(let x be a variable for the current hour)
Let's say that right now it is x o'clock (x:00).

x:15 -- quarter past x
x:30 -- half past x
x:45 -- quarter to x+1 (the next hour)
5:05, 5:10, 5:20, 5:25 --   minute   past x
5:35, 5:40, 5:50, 5:55 --  60-minute  to x+1
(minute represents the minute hand)
Look at the clock. Take turns saying the time with your partner.

Contractions 

A contraction is a word made by shortening
and combining two words
Examples: 
she is = she's 
does not = doesn't
do not = don't 
I am = I'm
I will = I'll

Used in a sentence: I'm eleven years old. He's going to school.

Grade 4 Math  -  Prime and Composite Numbers 


What are prime numbers?
Can you name any prime numbers?

What are composite numbers?
Can you name any composite numbers?

Vocabulary Review 

A prime number cannot be formed by multiplying 
two smaller whole numbers.
It is divisible by one and itself.
For example: 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13

A composite number can be formed by multiplying
two smaller whole numbers.
It is divisible by one, itself, and other numbers.
For example: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 14

to recognize prime numbers.

Watch this video to review what prime numbers are and 
how to do distinguish them from composite numbers.

Numbers like 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, and 11 are called prime numbers
 because they cannot be formed by multiplying two smaller whole 
numbers.

Numbers like 4, 6, 8, 9, and 10 are called composite numbers
 because they can be formed by multiplying two smaller whole 
numbers.

Intro to Grade 8 Science Unit 8: Sound 

Big Ideas
-Learn about measuring sound

Guiding Questions
-How does sound travel?
-How do we measure sound?
-How does sound work?

Sound Vocabulary 

Sound Wave
Wave Length
Frequency
Speed of Sound
Reflection of Sound
Echo
Reverberation

Vocab 1 

Sound Waves: Vibrations that are transmitted through solids, 
liquids, and gases, which are called mediums. 
This is how sound is transmitted.

Wave Length: The distance between each of the sound waves.
It is measured in meters and is indicated by lambda.

Frequency: The number of vibrations per second. It is
measured in Hertz (Hz). 
1 Kilohertz (KHz) = 1,000 Hz & 1 Megahertz (MHz) = 1,000,000 Hz
The velocity of a sound wave is the wave length multiplied by the
  frequency.

Vocab 2 

Speed of Sound: The speed of sound is equal to frequency 
multiplied by the wavelength of the sound.

Reflection of Sound: When sound hits an object, it reflects back.
 This is the process that can cause an echo.

Echo: The experience after sound is reflected is called an echo.
 Echoscan be discovered in small spaces with hard walls, like a 
canyon or cave.

Vocab 3 

Reverberation: The prolongation of an initial sound in large empty
 spaces, like a hallway.

velocity of sound = frequency * wavelength

Write down these definitions and move on to the next page.

travel through to reach the other cup?

23m, whatis the velocity of the sound wave?

Practice Problem 1

23m, what is the velocity of the sound wave?

V = f * wavelength
V = 13Hz * 23m
v = 299 m/s

Grade 1: Animals Reproduce

Do you have any animals at home?

Questions

Answers 

Do all animals have babies?
All animals have babies, but some lay eggs while others give birth
 to their babies. Animals, such as chicken and fish, lay eggs. 
Animals, such as cows and pigs, give birth to live babies.
Do all babies look the same?
No, not all babies look the same. Babies from the same species 
will look similar but not the same. Piglets (pig babies) look 
different from chicks (chicken babies). When you were a baby, 
you probably looked different from your friends even though you 
are both human beings!

Childbirth Video 

This video shows how human beings give birth. Notice that the 
baby is inside its mommy and not in an egg. 

Do you think human childbirth will be similar or different to the 
childbirth of other animals that give birth?

Childbirth Video Answer 

Do you think human childbirth will be similar or different to the 
childbirth of other animals that give birth?

Human childbirth is similar to the childbirth of other animals that
give birth. 

Talk with a partner.
Have you ever seen an egg hatch? What do you think it looks like?

Activity 

Look at the following image of eggs and think about these questions:

Which animal do you think these eggs came from?

How do you think the parents care for the eggs before they hatch?

Activity Answer 

These eggs are from different types of birds, such as ducks and 
chickens.
 
Notice that they are all different sizes and colors. Birds like 
these care for their eggs by sitting on them, which keeps the eggs
warm and helps them grow until they have enough energy to 
hatch. The next video shows how robins take care of their eggs.

  Have you ever seen a hen sitting on her eggs?

Activity 

Look at the following image of eggs and think about these questions:

What animal do you think these eggs came from?

How do you think the parents care for the eggs before they hatch?

Activity Answer 

These are frog's eggs. Notice how they are underwater. When the
eggs hatch, tadpoles come out, not frogs. Tadpoles can only live in
the water and have a tail to help them swim faster. When they 
get older, the tail disappears and the tadpoles develop into frogs
with legs. They can go on land and water.

Have you ever seen a tadpole before?
A tadpole is an immature frog.

Concluding Questions 

What are two ways animals reproduce?

Draw an animal that gives birth next to an animal that lays eggs. 
Hang your drawings up around the classroom!

Challenge: Can you spell the name of the animals that you drew?

Grade 1 Lesson 7 and 8: Addition and Subtraction Up to Five 

Turn to a partner and try to solve these warmup problems.
1. At lunch, you have one apple. Your friend decides that they don't
 want their apple and give it to you. How many apples do you have 
now? Is this an addition or subtraction problem?
2. You have four buttons. Your friend loves buttons so you give him
 one. How many buttons do you have now? 
Is this an addition or subtraction problem?

Let's look at some more examples of addition and subtraction!

Intro Answers 

1. You now have two apples. You had one apple before but then 
your friend gave you one, 1 + 1 = 2. 
This is an addition problem because you are 
adding things, not taking them away.
2. You now have three buttons. You had four before but then 
you gave your friend one, 4 - 1 = 3. 
This is a subtraction problem because you are taking
away a button and not adding one.

Addition Videos 

Watch the following video and on a piece of paper, write down 
the problems.
Try to solve them along with the video. 
You may work with a partner.

Addition Video Practice 

Now, try to solve the following problem alone:
2 + 3 = ?
You may draw it out if that helps.

Addition Video Practice Answer 

2 + 3 = 5!
Let's draw it out.
OO + OOO = OOOOO.
If you have two circles and gain three, you now have five circles!

Now, let's watch another video for more practice. Follow along.
  
Try to solve the problems with the video. 
You may work with a partner.

Addition Video Practice 

Now, try to solve the following problems alone. Once you are finished,
check your answers with a partner.

#4. 5 + 0 = ?
#5. 2 + 1 = ?

Addition Video Practice Answers 

#1. 1 + 4 = 5
#2. 2 + 2 = 4
#3. 3 + 1 = 4
#4. 5 + 0 = 5
#5. 2 + 1 = 3

Subtraction 

Now let's learn about subtraction! Read the textbook lesson and complete the
practice problems.

Subtraction Videos

and try to solve them along with the video. You may work with a partner.

Now, try to solve the following problem alone:

You may draw it out if that helps.

Subtraction Video Practice Answer 

5 - 2 = 3!
Let's draw it out.
OOOOO - OO = OOO.
If you have five circles and take away two, you now have three circles!

Now, let's watch another video for more practice. Please follow along and 
try to solve the problems with the video. You may work with a partner.

Now, try to solve the following problems alone. Once you are finished,

#5. 1 - 1 = ?

Class 6 Math: Sets 

Sets: a collection of distinct objects that have something in 
common.

What are some examples of sets?

Describing Sets 

Describing sets: One way that we can define sets without a venn 
diagram is by describing what's in the set.

For example, if we have a set that includes a chair, couch, table
and a bed then we can describe the set by 
saying: a set of furniture.

Turn to the next page to learn about another way to notate a set.

Listing Sets 

Listing sets: This is the most common method for notating sets
and the one you will see most often going forward in math. 
For this notation, we assign the set a name (usually an uppercase
letter) and then put everything in the set in between brackets.

For example, if we had a set of the letters in the alphabet up 
to F, we would say the following:
X = {A, B, C, D, E, F}

Turn to the next page to learn the final way to describe a set.

Building Sets 

Building Sets: Building sets is sort of similar to describing sets. 
You assign a variable to the set and then describe it.

For example, if we had a set of clothing you would say:

{x:x is clothing items}

Move on to the next page to learn about membership of a set.

Membership of a Set 

Membership: We also have a way of notating whether something
is in a set.
For example, if we have the following set:
A = {a, b, c, d}
So we know that, b is a part of the set. We would use a symbol 
that looks like an E to notate this.
b E A
This means be is a part of set A. If it wasn't a part of the set,
we would draw a line through the E.

Move on to the next page to do a practice problem.

Before ePaath 

Turn to the next page and do the ePaath as a class.

Ask any questions if they come up!

After ePaath 

Now that we have reviewed what sets are let's move on to new 
ideas!

In the next few slides we are going to learn about set notation
Ask questions as they come up!

We know how to visualize sets using venn diagrams but how about 
when we want to write a set out without a venn diagram. What 
should we do?

Practice Problem 1 

We have a set of all the vowels in the alphabet. Notate this set
using the describing, listing and building methods!

Practice Problem 1 
 Answers 

We have a set of all the vowels in the alphabet. Notate this set
using the describing, listing and building methods!

Describing: a set of all of the vowels in the alphabet
Listing: A = {a, e, i, o u}
Building: {x:x are the vowels in the alphabet}

Practice Problem 2 

We have a set including a television, cell phone, car, and a 
calculator.
Describe this set using all three methods we learned.

Practice Problem 2 
 Answers 

We have a set including a television, cell phone, car, and a 
calculator.
Describe this set using all three methods we learned.

Describing: a set of electronic devices
Listing: A = {television, cell phone, car, calculator}
Building: {x:x are electronic devices}

Practice Problem 3 

Make your own! With a partner, make a set of something and
have another group notate it using the three methods 
we have learned.

Review 

In this lesson, we learned methods to notate sets. They were: 
describing,listing and building.

We also learned about membership of sets.

Make sure you take note of these methods and how to do them. 
They will be useful to you in the future!

Make sure you ask questions if you have any.

What was your favorite method to notate sets? Why?
