        Translated by: Raj & Abhi         Date: 07/29/2020

Grade 6  Math  
 Add and Subtract Decimals 
The slide order & teaching strategies of the textbook are:
1) Objectives and Vocabulary
2) Opener: Make objectives relevant and interesting personally
3) Instruction: Read the textbook and practice vocabulary
4) Exploration: Practice concepts with new resources and activities
5) Assessment: Prove they can apply the learned material 
6) Reflection on Lesson: Write or speak or share about what 
they learned and how well they did personally
Active learning strategies used in this lesson are:  
Lining up the numbers, thinking logically, and pair/share

Objectives and Vocabulary: 


Objectives:

When you finish this lesson you will be able to:

1. Add decimal numbers using the concept of carrying

2. Subtract decimal numbers using the concept of borrowing. 


Vocabulary:

decimal number, place value

\ 2) Opener 

Opener 


What is an example of a decimal number?

How would you represent 1/2 as a decimal number?

If 15 has a 1 in the tens place and a 5 in the one place,

what are the place values of 239 (hundreds, tens, ones)?

What are the place values of 47.5 (tens, ones, tenths)?

Write the number 8 64/100 as a decimal number.


Discuss these questions with a partner to better understand

some of the vocabulary before the lesson.

Instruction: Before the textbook 

Read the text as directed by your teacher.

Look for information on how "carrying over" and "borrowing"
helps you to add or subtract decimal numbers.

Think/Write/Share: What questions do you have?
What new information or ideas are in this resource?

Instruction: After the textbook 

Discuss the following questions with a partner:

What did you learn about adding
and subtracting decimal numbers?

Why is it important to understand place value when
adding and subtracting decimal numbers?

What questions do you have?

Instruction: Vocabulary 


Breakout into groups of 2 or 3 people. Pick one of the following:

3,4,7

5,6,8

1,9,3

2,8,7

5,4,9

Make different numbers with those digits.


Write the smallest possible decimal number and identify the 

place values. Write the largest possible number and identify 

the place values.

E

Exploration: Before a Resource


Watch the “adding decimals example 1” and 

“subtracting decimals” videos on the following slides. 

As you watch the videos, think about and be prepared to 

discuss the following questions with a partner…


What new information or ideas are in this resource?

How might adding or subtracting a decimal be different

from adding and subtracting whole numbers?

What questions do you have?

Exploration: After a Resource


Find someone with whom you haven’t talked today

and discuss the videos and these questions:


What do you think is easier: to add or subtract decimal numbers?


What is the most important rule when adding

or subtracting decimal numbers? 


How will adding and subtracting decimal numbers

be useful in your everyday life?

Exploration

Solve the Word Problems
    Suppose the market is 5.85 kilometers away.You have 
    walked 2.34 kilometers. How much farther must you go?

        Suppose I have 2 bottles of water. One has 1.34 liters.
          The other has 1.68 liters. I drink .76 liters from one bottle.
            How many liters of water remain in the bottles?

Exploration

Solve the Word Problems

    walked 2.34 kilometers. How much farther must you go?
      (3.51)
        Suppose I have 2 bottles of water. One has 1.34 liters.
          The other has 1.68 liters. I drink .76 liters from one bottle.

2. Assessment 

Answer True or False:

9.182 - 8.863= 0.729 

1629.294 + 1.9270 = 1631.224

12.09 - 4.123 = 7.967

How many km did I travel in total?

How tall is Josh?

False, False, True

2. Reflection on Lesson


Reflect on the lesson


Individuals, pairs, or small groups respond orally or in writing.


What makes adding and subtracting decimal numbers

Introduction to Grade 4 Science: Safe Environment and Health Life
Objectives and Vocabulary 

  When you have finished this lesson, you will:

      1) Determine whether an item is degradable or non-degradable
      2) Understand how degradable and non-degradable waste is 
        repurposed.
Vocabulary:
Degradable, Non-degradable, waste, garbage, compost, clean

Opener 

Answer the following questions in your notebook.

What are 5 things you and your family throw away in your house?
Does your house separate degradable and non-degradable waste?
  Why is it important to separate degradable and non-degradable
waste?

Exploration - After video 

As a class discuss the following questions

How does compost help the environment?

What are some items you can compost in your homes?

Assessment 

1. Look around the school for any waste.

2. Decide with a partner if it is degradable or non-degradable.

3. With your classmates, build a home or school compost box 
    or bin. Instruct others what may go in or does not go in.
    Maintain the compost bin for the school year and give it 
    to the next grade to continue.

Reflection 

With a partner, share one thing you learned and will
use in your daily life.

Answer this question in your notebook:
What can you do in your home or village to help 
separate degradable and non-degradable waste?

Made by: Faiz & Carol            Date: 2024/03/05

Translated by: firstname(s)         Date: YYMMDD

Objectives and Vocabulary 

When you finish this Lesson you will be able to:
-Throw an ball safely.

Vocabulary:
throw, playing, ball

Instruction 



1. What is throwing?
2. How do you throw a ball?

Discuss these questions with your partner.

Exploration: Throwing Games 

Choose a partner for the following activity.

While throwing the ball with your partner keep track of
how many times each of you drop the ball. Try your best 
not drop the ball when it is thrown to you.

After each of you has thrown the ball 10 times, determine
who dropped the ball less. They are the winner.

Reflection  

Discuss the following questions with a partner.

1. What did you learn about throwing?

2.What are some strategies you used
to throw the ball successfully?

Lesson Credits 



Made by: Adam and Nan          Date: 2020/07/29

Translated by: firstname(s)         Date: YYMMDD

Objectives and Vocabulary 

Objectives
When you finish the lesson you will be able to:
- Practice running, jogging, and zig-zagging.

Vocabulary
Running, Jogging, Zig-zagging

Types of Running

Name all the different types of running
that you can think of.

Discuss with a partner for one minute.

Next, have a class discussion to make sure
everyone has similar answers.

Exploration - Relay Races 
1. Split the class into five groups. Establish a finish line.
2. The groups will get into five lines and move
twenty paces away from the finish line.
3. When the teacher starts the game, one student from each
group will run to the finish line and then back to their group.
4. When the runner returns to their group, the next student
begins their run to the finish line.
5. The first group to have every member run
to the finish line and return, wins.
6. Each round, the teacher will say a new way of running
(jog, zig-zag, etc.) and the students must do that exercise.
Play as many rounds as your teacher wants.

Exploration - Treasure Hunters 
1. Split the class into five new groups.
2. Each group starts with five balls/rocks/pencils
 (use what you have).
3. Spread out the groups with even space between them and place
the balls/rocks/pencils etc. in that area.
4. When the teacher starts the game, each group will run to 
capture the other groups's items. 
5. When you take an item from a different group, run back
and place the item in your group's area.
6. Whichever team has the most items after 5 minutes wins.
7. Play as many times as the teacher wants.
Continue to the next slide for more instructions

Reflection 

Discuss these questions with a partner:

1. What was your favorite activity from this lesson?

2. Do you play any other games that involve running?

3. What types of running are there?

Lesson Credits 


Made by: Chase              Date: 200729

Translated by: Raj and Abhi         Date: 200729

Objectives and Vocabulary 

Objectives
When you finish the lesson you will be able to:
-Be able to act out different types of
characters and emotions
- Learn how to tell stories

Vocabulary
story, role play, imitation, gestures

Instruction


 There are different types of stories such as stories with morals, 
modern day stories, and child and folk
 stories.
What kind of stories do you like to listen to?

Game
 Play this short story game with the class.
1. Everyone sits in a big circle, and one student
      says a sentence to start the story of his/her choice. 
         2. Each following student adds a sentence to the
         story until everyone has added to the story.

Reminder: there are different types of stories.

After you finish the game, discuss with your class:
Did you enjoy the game? What did you like about it?
If you didn't like it, how would you change the game?

Exploration: Role Play Games 

In a role play you act or perform a person or character.
Everyone in the class will be on a two-person team. 
Imagine that you are on the moon. You are astronauts. 
Create a 1 minute story of what you might do on the moon.
Any story is ok; use your imagination!
Perform your story in front of the class.
Once done, each team answers the following questions:
Did you enjoy the game? What did you like about it?
If you didn't like it, how would you change the game?

Exploration: Imitation Games 
To imitate is to simulate using gestures of face or hand.
Split the class into two teams. There will be three rounds.
In each round one person from each team stands in front
of their team and acts out different emotions. The teacher
can change the category (ex. animals, people). If the
performer's team is able to guess the emotion in 30
seconds, that team gets 1 point. The most points win!
Once done, answer the following questions with your partner:
Did you enjoy the game? What did you like about it?
If you didn't like it, how would you change the game?

Reflection 

Let's pair share: discuss the following questions.
     1) What was your favorite type of game that we played
in this lesson (short story, role play, imitation)? 
2) What kind of other games would you like to play?
        3) Do you like acting? Why do you feel this way?

In this world, there are people who do acting as a job.
They perform in musicals and plays across the world.

Lesson Credits 

     Made by: Mitsuka and Nan                   Date: 07/30/2020    
  Translated by: ----         Date: ----

Introduction to Grade 4 Science: Our Food 
 Objectives and Vocabulary 

After finishing this lesson, students will:
 - Identify different types of food eaten in the three Nepal
   regions: Himal, Hilly and Terai
- Recognize the nutritional differences between pre-packaged
   foods and fresh foods

Vocabulary
millet, pulses, wheat, barley, rice, iodine

Opener 

In small groups, answer the following questions:

What sorts of foods do you eat at home?

Which food is your favorite?

Exploration: Before ePaath 

The following resource is an ePaath called "Foods I Eat"

Complete it as a class.

Exploration: After ePaath 

To avoid getting sick it is important not to eat
stale or rotten food.

It is important not to eat too much
spicy, sweet, or junk foods.

What do you need to eat to be healthy? 
Give specific examples.

Exploration: Favorite Dish 

Have a Healthy Food Festival!
For your next class, each student make a favorite dish 
with your family and bring it to the class to share.
Write a small recipe card for others to see and copy. 

After trying other dishes, 
discuss the different spice, smells, and colors.
Which ones are the most healthy?

Reflection 

Pair-share or in small groups
and answer the following questions:

What did you learn about the food you eat?

Will you change your current eating habits? If so, how?

Objectives and Vocabulary 

When you finish this lesson you will be able to:


 a. Name and order the days of the week and months of the

      year using ordinal numbers.
 b. Identify rhyming words and sound similarities.
 c. Write correct verb endings for these ACTION verbs:
      to GO, to WRITE, to WORSHIP, to PLAY, to SING

  d. Speak, write or read the following new vocabulary.

Day  Week  Month  Ordinal Numbers  First-Tenth

Opener 


1. Study together a western calendar showing
              days, weeks, months, and the western year. 
2. Then add to the calendar the Nepali year in (parentheses)
    next to western year.
3. In notebooks, pairs of students will draw one month
    (month at the top) and fill in all days and dates. 
4. On the calendar, put your two birthdays (pair) and any
    holidays of that month.

Instruction: Vocabulary-1 

   

   Review Vocabulary Words:

   Day- 24 hours: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday,

                       Thursday, Friday, Saturday

   Week-A period of 7 consecutive days, starting with Sunday

   Month-One of the 12 divisions of the calendar year:

         January, February, March, April, May, June, July,

         August, September, October, November, December

   

   An old English poem about months is on the next page.

Instruction: Vocabulary-2 
 Ordinal Numbers 
    Play a game!
    a. Line up Short to Tall. -call out your ordinal
       number in the line.
    b. Line up by Birthday order- January-December- 
       call out your ordinal number in the line. 

1st (first) 2nd (second) 3rd (third) 4th (fourth)
5th (fifth) 6th (sixth) 7th (seventh) 8th (eighth)
9th (ninth) 10th (tenth) 12th (twelfth)
15th (fifteenth) 18(eighteenth)  20th (twentieth)

Exploration: Resource 2 


Rhyming Words 
  In teams of 4, work together to add English words
  that rhyme with the following word groups:
      See how many your group can find.
  1. cat, rat, sat, mat ____ ____ ____ ____ ____
  2. no, so, throw      ____ ____ ____ ____ ____
  3. dish, fish          ____ ____ ____ ____ ____
  4. dream, cream      ____ ____ ____ ____ ____
  Share with the class. Add the new words to your list
  in your copybook.

Exploration: Resource Introduction 


   The next video is about Ordinal Numbers.

   Listen, play the games, and repeat the words.

   Then make a new class game using ordinal numbers.


   Which ordinal number(s) is/are most difficult for you

     to remember?

Reflection on Videos 



   What did you think of the videos?

   What similarities did you notice?

   What differences?

   What skills does each game help you develop?

     (e.g. eye-hand coordination, reflexes for both...)

   Who has played marbles? (note: # boys, # girls)

   Who has played gatti (note: # boys, # girls)

   Do you sometimes lose a marble?

Reflection 


  Together as a class FILL IN a K.W.L. Chart on the board.


    KNOW-->What do you now know?
    WANT-->What do want to understand better?
    LEARN-->How will you use what you have learned?
                    

    Which activities used for this lesson help you learn

    the best?

Lesson Credits

dn: 3M07 Addition up to Four Digit Numbers

data.html:
Objectives and Vocabulary 

Objectives: When you finish this Lesson you will:

1. add 4 digit numbers

2. add 2, 3 and 4 digit numbers using 'carry over'


Vocabulary: digit, carry over, regroup

(definitions on next slide)

Vocabulary: when you finish this lesson you will:

1. write the ten digits in the Hindu Arabic number system

2. trace 5 of your digits (on either a hand or a foot)

3. write an addition problem that requires carry over

(regrouping) and one that does not.

Vocabulary 

Digit:

1. Finger, toe

1.a. any one of the whole numbers from 1 through 9

1.b. one of the 10 Arabic numerals by which all

numbers may be expressed


Carry over: o transfer an amount to the next column


  Regroup: to form a new grouping in order to add or

subtract (for example: ten 'ones' become one 'ten')

Opener 

     Note to teacher: write these symbols and numbers on the

   board and circle the + sign and the number 4.

   Answers are on the next slide.


     +  -  x  / (division symbol)

     1 2 3 4


     What do these symbols mean?

     Why is + circled?

     How many digits do you think the problems will have?

     Who can tell us what a digit is?

Helpful Hints and Answers to Questions 


   1. What do these symbols mean? Why is the + circled?

   Answer: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division...

   We are going to work on:  addition


   2. How many digits do you think the problems will have?

   Answer: 4


   3. Who can tell us what a digit is?

   Discuss digits as single numerals and also as fingers and

   toes which can help us do math problems.

Exploration: Introduction to Adding 4-digit Numbers 


Who will write a 1 digit addition problem on the board?

Who will change this to a 2 digit, 3 digit or 4 digit problem?


Solve the problem with class input, noting any carry over if it

was needed. Discuss carry over as a term for regrouping.


If carry over was not needed, write a 4 digit problem that

requires carry over and solve with class input. Then discuss

carry over/regrouping.

Exploration: Video Adding 4-digit numbers 


Watch the video on the next slide

Then answer this question:


Who knows a word that means the same as 'carry over'?

Exploration: Resource Introduction on Punctuation 


1. Watch the video

2. Play this 'punctuation challenge' (to reinforce the word

"digit". Work with the class to solve this by reading aloud

as it is presented, and then again, pause when the words

make sense to the class. At each pause, add punctuation.


every lady in this land

has 20 digits on each hand

5 and 20 on hands and feet

and this is true without deceit

Exploration: Resource Review 

 Answer to Punctuation Quiz 



Every lady in this land

has 20 digits. On each hand

5, and 20 on hands and feet,

and this is true without deceit.

Assessment 

Students will demonstrate that they have learned the lesson

material well enough to remember, understand, apply, analyze,

evaluate, and create.           A    B

34   72

+87 +59

=121 =121

Students: Copy and check these calculations in your copybook.

One is correct, one is not. On a paper scrap write the letter

(A or B) of the incorrect problem and the correct answer.

Give it to the teacher. The teacher will share how many

found A incorrect and how many found B incorrect.

Lesson Credits

Introduction to Grade 4 Math Unit 5 Chapter 2 Money 


The slide order & teaching strategies of this lesson are:

1) Opener: make lesson relevant and engaging

2) Objectives and Vocabulary

3) Instruction: study the textbook

4) Exploration: activities and resources

5) Assessment of Objectives: students demonstrate learning

6) Reflection: students tell thoughts and feelings about lesson

Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 

Partners Assess Vocabulary,  Game "Guess the Category",

Group Problem Solving, Matching

Opener 

   

   Who can guess the category (subject) for this word

   and the following words? 

     elephant  

   Write this word and the following words on the board.

   After each word, give students a chance to guess the 

   category.

   If someone guesses the category before the list is

   complete, have the class try to add the names for the 

   rest of the list.

Opener 


   Now write black buck on the board

Opener 


   Now write yak on the board

Opener 


   Now write tahr on the board.

Opener 


   Now write sambar (swamp deer) on the board.


   Can anyone guess the category of all of these words?

Opener 


   Now write snow leopard on the board.

Opener 


   Now write tiger on the board.


   Can anyone guess the category of these words yet?

Opener 


   Now write one-horned rhinoceros on the board.

Opener - Answers 


   The category for these words is:


   animals on our paper money!

Opener - continued 


   1. List the denominations of Nepali currency

      from Rs.2 to Rs.100 on the board.

   2. Make a separate list on the board of the animals

      on Nepali currency. 

   3. Call on different students to match the denomination

      to the paper currency by drawing a connecting line

      to one of the animals.

   4. Erase the board. Tell the class "As I name an animal

      on our currency, write the # of Rupees it represents

      in your copybook and hold it up for me to see."

Opener - continued 


   Discuss images on Nepali Rs.1 and Rs.2 coins. 

   What do you notice? 

   What image is on one side of every piece

    of Nepali currency?


   Tell class "We will learn more about money today".

Opener - Answers 


   What do you notice on the Rs.1 and Rs.2 coins? 

   Answer: no animals


   What image is on one side of every piece

    of Nepali currency?

   Answer: Mount Everest

Objectives 


Objectives: When you finish this lesson, you will:


1. identify coin and paper money: Rs.1, Rs.2, Rs.5, Rs.10, 

Rs.20, Rs.25, Rs.50, Rs.100, Rs.500, Rs.1000

2. convert paisas to rupees

3. convert rupees to paisas

4. add rupees and paisas 

5. use one or more mathematical operations (+, -, x, /) 

to solve problems involving paisas and rupees

6. match currency amount to currency image

Vocabulary 


Vocabulary: when you finish this lesson you will define:


1. Rupee: unit of Nepali currency equal to 100 paisas

2. paisa: unit of Nepali currency, 1/100 of a Rupee

3. endangered species: a species (type of animal) likely to 

   become extinct in the near future

Instruction: Vocabulary 

 

   1. paisa: Nepali currency, 1/100 of a Rupee

   2. Rupee: Nepali currency, equals 100 paisa

   3. endangered species: a species (group of animals)

      likely to become extinct in the near future


   Students should do the following activity:

   In pairs, quiz each other (one partner say word, other 

    partner give definition, then do this in reverse)

Exploration: Resource Introduction 


   The following resource is about Nepali currency. 

   It is from: Gundrukpost.com, Nepalese Notes Among

    World's Most Beautiful: Represent Animals.

   Read this article (several children read aloud

   to the rest of class). Share with a partner your

   favorite Nepali bank note and tell why. Teacher tallies

   favorites on board and has class discuss results.

   Did anyone expect different results? Why?

Exploration: Resource Introduction 


   Who knows the name of an endangered animal

   on a Nepali banknote?


   Record answers on board. Read out loud the next slide

   and correct answers if necessary. 

   Discuss text and images.

Exploration: Resource (p 1 of 3) 

Nepalese banknotes spread awareness of endangered species.

Nepalese currency is considered to be one of the most

beautiful currencies of the world. It is beautifully decorated

with various symbols and pictures that reflect the identity and

sovereignty of Nepal. All of the Nepalese currency have a

picture of an animal imprinted on the back of the currency.

Most of this animals are among the endangered animals of

Nepal. Most recently the National Bank of Nepal has taken a

very appreciable step to issue new bank notes with the aim of

spreading awareness among the people about the danger of

extinction which the animals are facing in Nepal.

Exploration: Resource (p 2 of 3) 

The new issued notes in 2017 consist of imprinted pictures of
endangered animals that sends a very powerful message to the
public. The old notes of Rs.10 had an image of three black
bucks grazing in the field but since their numbers are
decreasing currently due to poaching, the newly issued
banknotes of Rs.10 has an image of only one black buck
grazing in the same field as shown in the first image.
Similarly the old banknote of Rs.5 had an image of two
Himalayan Yaks imprinted on the back but now the new note
has replaced it with an image of only one Yak. Also the image
of sheep in the old Rs.50 note has been replaced by an image
of snow leopard, symbolizing a new animal being endangered.

Exploration: Resource (p 3 of 3) 

The new banknotes have also spread some positive vibes. The
new note of Rs.100 has an image of a mother One-horn rhino
along with her calf while the older one had image of only one
rhino. This represents that the number of endangered One-
horn rhino is increasing in Nepal. Similarly the new bank note
of Rs.20 has imprinted image of two swamp deer replacing the
image of single swamp deer.

So lastly let's hope that this will spread some positive

awareness among the people and there will be an increase

in the number of endangered animals of Nepal.

Exploration: Resource Introduction 


   Money hasn't always been in the form of coins and paper

   bills. Do you know what has been used

   as money in the past?


   Teacher: record the ideas on the board.


   Watch the following 3 minute video to learn what has been

   used as money. See if any of your ideas are in the video.

Assessment 

Students demonstrate that they have learned the lesson

material well enough to remember, understand, and apply.


  1. For assessment of objectives 1 and 5, children carried out

     teacher-led exercises in Opener.


  2. For assessment of objectives 2, 3, and 4, children 

     independently completed chapter exercise, 5.5

  

     If any student has not mastered the material, he/she

     should go back and redo the exercises.

Reflection 


Who will share one thing you learned today for the first 

time? Teacher records student contributions.

What do you want to know more about? Teacher records 

answers.

Who wants to tell your parents about this lesson?

What, specifically, do you want to tell them?

Based on student answers to questions above, discuss one or

more topics (e.g. endangered species) and how children might

impact this issue through community action.

Lesson Credits 


Made by: Joanna              Date: 210330


Translated by: first name(s)         Date: YYMMDD

Introduction to Grade 4 Math  Unit 4 Chapter 2  

 Decimal Number 

The slide order & teaching strategies of this lesson are:

1) Objectives & Vocabulary

2) Opener: Make objectives relevant & interesting personally

3) Instruction: Read textbook & explore other resources

4) Exploration: Practice concepts with resources & activities

5) Assessment: Prove students can apply the learned material

6) Reflect on Lesson: Write or speak on what they learned

& how the lesson connects to their life, society & the world

Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 

Thumbs up/down to check for understanding  decimal game with

die (play in pairs)  group share

Objectives 


Objectives: When you finish this Lesson you will be able to:

1.  Identify a shaded section as a fraction of its whole

2.  Write a fraction as a decimal

3.  Write a decimal as a fraction

4.  Add decimal numbers

5.  Subtract decimal numbers

6.  Express rupees and paisas as decimals

7.  Express meters and centimeters as decimals

8.  Write an amount as a fraction, then as a decimal, then

as a percentage

Introduction to Grade 4 Math Unit 5 Chapter 3: Distance 

The slide order & teaching strategies of this lesson are:

1) Objectives & Vocabulary

2) Opener: make lesson relevant and engaging

3) Instruction: study the textbook

4) Exploration: activities & resources

5) Assessment: students demonstrate learning

6) Reflection: students tell thoughts and feelings about lesson


Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 

Think Pair/Group Share, Matching, Hand Check, Drawing 

Cooperative Learning Groups, Brainstorming

Objectives 


Objectives: When you finish this Lesson you will be able to:


1. Identify the number of mm in 1 cm

2. Identify the number of cm in 1 m

3. Identify the number of m in 1 km

4. Convert km to m, m to cm, cm to mm, and the reverse

5. Given something to measure, determine the best unit to use

6. Measure objects and distances using mm, cm, m, and km

7. Solve word problems involving measurement

Vocabulary (page 1) 


Vocabulary: when you finish this lesson you will

understand and use these words:


   1. millimeter (mm): 1/1000 of a meter

   2. centimeter (cm): 1/100 of a meter

   3. meter (m): 100 centimeters or 1000 millimeters

   4. kilometer (km): 1000 meters

   5. wingspan: distance from fingertips to fingertips

       when arms are outstretched horizontally

   6. outstretch: extended or stretched out

Vocabulary (page 2) 


Vocabulary: when you finish this lesson, you will

understand and use these words:


7. Vitruvian Man: a 1490 drawing by Leonardo da Vinci of a

    person inside a circle and a square, with arms and legs in

    two different superimposed positions, to demonstrate

    "ideal" body proportions, i.e. wingspan equal to height

8. anatomy: the structure and parts of the body

Instruction: Vocabulary  


Instruction for terms 1-4 is in the Opener


Instruction for terms 5 (wingspan) and 7 (Vitruvian Man) are

 taught in Measurement Activity, Exploration 1


Term 8 (anatomy) is discussed in Exploration Resources 3&4 

youtube videos:

   Drawing Vitruvian Man, and

   Why was Leonardo da Vinci so famous?

Opener (page 1) 


Who can tell us the name

of a unit of measurement for length?

   Teacher:

     list the (4) student responses in a column

     list the definitions randomly in a separate column

   Students:

     a student matches the first term with its definition

     class: who agrees with that? (use Hand Check)

     continue with 2nd, 3rd, and 4th vocabulary terms

Opener (page 2) 


  Students:

   four students take turns reading each objective

    1. Identify the number of mm in 1 cm

    2. Identify the number of cm in 1 m

    3. Identify the number of m in 1 km

    4. Convert km to m, m to cm, cm to mm, and the reverse

  Which objectives have you already met? Hand Check!

  Complete the chapter exercises and then you will be ready

   for a special Vitruvian Man measurement activity.

Exploration 3: Resource Instruction 


  Who knows what anatomy is?

  Take responses and form a definition of anatomy.


  Introduce Leonardo da Vinci from 15th century Italy.

  He studied anatomy.


  He believed that, in an ideally proportioned body, wingspan

  and height would be equal.


  His famous drawing, Vitruvian Man, illustrates this belief.

Exploration 4: Resource Instruction 


The next video teaches us about Leonardo's life.


Watch and learn why he is considered one of

the most remarkable people who ever lived.

Exploration 4: Resource Review 


You have learned that Leonardo was a painter, inventor,

sculptor, architect, philosopher, engineer, and scientist.


    Students:

     What does a person in each of these professions do?


     Which of these professions would you like to do? Why?


     Write a 2 or 3 sentence answer. If you wish, share

      your answer with the class.

Exploration 4: Resource Review (continued) 


If Leonardo da Vinci were alive today, what would you

like to tell him? ask him? talk to him about?


Share your answers in groups of 3 and then

share your ideas with the class.

Exploration 1: Vitruvian Man Measurement Activity 


 One student show the class a 'human wingspan'

 Work in groups of 3 to measure and record each other's 

 wingspan and height with lengths of string.

 Then measure (vertically) and record your face and hand.

 On the board make a chart for each student's measurements

 and in groups of 3 discuss the patterns you see, and share

 your answers with the class:

         Name   Height   Wingspan   Face   Hand

Exploration 2: Resource Introduction 


 The resource on the following slide shows a 3rd grade class

  in the United States who explored the relationship of the

  measurements of wingspan and height and of hand and

  face as you have just done.


 Watch and see if these children discovered what you have

 discovered. Teacher leads a class discussion of the video.

Exploration 3: Resource Instruction (continued) 


  Follow the video (on the next slide) and use measurement 

  skills to make your own drawing of the Vitruvian Man.


  You will need paper, pencil, ruler, and protractor. (If no

  protractors, prepare cut-out circles for students to trace).


  Play the video, pause and replay when necessary.

Quick! Here is a matching game! 


Choose 2, 3 or 4 teams.

Have fun with the game!

Assessment (page 1 of 2) 


   Students: Now you can demonstrate that you have learned

    the lesson material well enough to remember, understand,

    apply, analyze, evaluate, and create.


Be prepared to answer these questions:

How many mm are in 1 cm?

How many mm are in 1 m?

How many cm are in 1 m?

How many m are in 1 km?

Assessment (page 2 of 2) 


   Students: Now you can demonstrate that you have learned

    the lesson material well enough to remember, understand,

    apply, analyze, evaluate, and create.

Students: complete your answers to the questions in

Exercises 5.6, 5.7, and 5.8 (see next slide) and

be prepared to share your answer in class when

you are asked by your teacher.


Bonus question: What image is on the Euro coin?

Write your answer on a paper and give it to the teacher.

Reflection 


Students: What was difficult for you in this lesson?

Teacher: Record the answers.Discuss as a class.


Students: What did you enjoy about the lesson?

Teacher: Record the answers.Discuss as a class.


What about this lesson might you share with your parents?

Think when you or a friend measured something.

Make a list of these instances with a partner, and

share with the class.

Introduction to Grade 4 Science  Unit 2 Chapter 10 

 Safety Against Accidents 


The slide order & teaching strategies of this lesson are:

1) Objectives & Vocabulary: what a student will be able to do

2) Opener: make lesson relevant & engaging

3) Instruction: study the textbook

4) Exploration: practice with activities & resources

5) Assessment: students demonstrate learning

6) Reflection: students tell thoughts & feelings about lesson

   Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 

   Think Pair/Group Share  KWL  Brainstorming

Objectives 


Objectives: When you finish this Lesson you will:

  1. List places where accidents may occur

  2. Identify situations which may cause accidents

  3. Demonstrate safety measures to avoid:

Drowning

 Burns

 Animal bites/snakebites

 Electric shock

 Frostbite

Vocabulary 


Vocabulary: when you finish this lesson you will be able to use:


   Accident - An unfortunate incident that happens

   unexpectedly and unintentionally causing damage or injury.


   Safety - Freedom from the occurrence of rish of injury,

   danger or loss.


   Frostbite - A condition in which the skin and tissue just 

   below the skin freeze.

Opener 


   KWL - Teacher makes a KWL chart on the board. Students

   copy the chart in their copybooks. Brainstorm what you 

   know and want to know about personal safety.


   Share an accident you have observed with the class.


   What accidents have you heard about?


   What would you lilke to know about how to avoid these

   accidents?

Instruction: Vocabulary  


Accident   Safety   Frostbite


   1. With a partner define the vocabulary words and give

      an example of each.


   2. Act out each vocabulary word and have the class guess

      its meaning.

Exploration: Resource Introduction 


   The following resource is a Youtube video about being safe

   in your home.


   Watch this video and look for how to be safe.


   Be prepared to share the examples with the class.

Exploration: Resource Review 



   What did you learn about how to avoid accidents at home?

   Write these safety tips under "Learn" in your copybook.


   How does being aware of safety help one avoid accidents?

   Share examples of this with your class.

Assessment 


   Working with a partner write in your copybook a safety

   measure and describe where each of the following accidents

   might occur:

     Drowning

     Burns

     Animal or snakebite

     Electric Shock

     Frostbite


   Share these safety tips with the class.

Reflection 


   Share what you learned about safety with the class.


   Your teacher will write them in a list under "Learn" on the

   board.


   Discuss with the class:

     What about this lesson will you tell your parents,

     students or other adults?

     How couild this information help them?

     How can this new information be used in your community?

Lesson Credits 




Made by: Nan                  Date: 210402


Translated by: first name(s)       Date: YYMMDD

Objectives and Vocabulary 

When you finish this Lesson you will be able to:

- Play fun games
- Know to be active to win the game

Vocabulary:
chasing, interesting, squirrel

Exploration: Simple fun game 

Squirrel in Tree:
1. Students are divided into groups of 3 students.
2. Two students join hands to make a tree.
3. The third student stands inside the tree or circle 
to represent a squirrel. 
4. Leave a couple of squirrels without homes.
5. When the teacher starts the game, squirrels must leave 
home and find another home. 
6. The squirrels that do not find a tree are encouraged 
to find a tree in next round.
Play as many rounds as your teacher wants.

Reflection 

Discuss these questions with a partner:

1.Did you enjoy playing this game? Why?
2. Do you play any other games that involve running?

Lesson Credits

Objectives 


Objectives: 

When students finish this lesson they will:

Be able to make an upper case B and lower case b 

Identify the sound of /b/ at the beginning of words

  Say and use five or more words that begin with /b/

Instruction: Lesson Bb 

Stand up if you saw a brown bunny and blue berries.

Sit down if you saw a blue bike. Are you sitting or standing? 


Do the next lesson to practice writing B and b on paper.

What are some new B words? 

Read the story together, saying each line after your teacher.

With your partner: Count the number of B words.

What are story words that rhyme? Write them on the board. 

Go to the next slide and sing the story with a boy and guitar.

Do you see the black sheep? It is in Iceland where it is cold.

Can you hear the guitar? There is a picture of a guitar too.

Objectives and Vocabulary 

When you finish this Lesson you will be able to:

- Do different types of jumping
-Be active doing fun jumping in a physical game

Vocabulary:
jumping, hopping, skipping

Opener 

Discuss with a partner.
What do you know about different types of jumping?
Jumping is an activity we do with our body to keep it active.
We want to stay active so we can be healthy.

Jumping is fun to do by yourself or in a group with friends.
Do you know how to hop on one foot? Demonstrate for your partner.
Do you know how to skip?  Show your partner.
Do you know how to jump?  Show your partner.

Exploration: Different types of jumping 
Hopping and changing direction

1. Choose a partner. Partner A stands on one line. Partner B 
stands on a line 5 meters away facing her partner.
2.  The students in the first group hop on one foot to their partner
on the second line, touch their hand, turn, and hop back to their 
first position.
3. The students in the second group repeat that action.

Exploration: Different types of jumping 
Skipping

1. Two students pick up and hold the ends of a rope.
2. Students stoop down and shake the ends of the rope.
3.The rest of the students form a line and take turns jumping 
over the wiggling rope without stepping on it.

Students can jump moving a rope in different ways.
Play several rounds taking turns holding the rope and jumping.

Assessment 

Questions:
1. Give as many reasons as you can why physical exercises
like different types of jumping is important.
2. Name different types of jumping 
you have tried in this lesson. What other kinds of jumping can you
describe?
 
3. What happens if you don't do physical activities?

Reflection 

Discuss the following questions with a partner.
Then share with the full class.

1.What was your favorite jumping from this lesson?
2. Do you play any other games that involve jumping?

Lesson Credits 

Made by: Amrita and Nan            Date: 210724

Translated by: Amrita        Date: 2107

Grade 1 English; Unit 1 Chapter 14:
 Lines and Shapes 

Let's learn more about shapes and lines.

Shapes include:
 LINES   CIRCLES   SQUARES   RECTANGLES  TRIANGLES   

   You will learn more later!

Objectives and Vocabulary 

When you are finished, you will be able to:

1. Copy and identify different lines. These will be the beginning
    of writing!
2. Match and copy different lines and shapes               


Vocabulary:
      Shapes, lines, angles, triangles, circles, rectangles

Exploring Lines and Shapes 
 Listen and Act 

Let's learn more about lines and shapes  .

 LINE   CIRCLE   SQUARE   RECTANGLE  TRIANGLE   

                     Lines make our shapes.

Teachers Intro to Lesson: Grade 2 English Unit 2 Lesson 7 
 Before School 

The slide order and teaching strategies of the textbook are :
1) Objectives and Vocabulary 
2) Opener: Make the objective relevant and interesting
3) Instruction: Read the textbook and practice vocabulary 
4) Exploration: Practice concepts with resources and activities
Provided 
5) Assessment: Prove that they can apply the learned material
6) Reflection of lesson: Write or speak about what they 
learned and how well they did personally

Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 
Pair/ group share, Questioning and Brainstorming

Objective and Vocabulary 

Objectives:- 
By the end of the chapter students will be able to: 
1) Learn to wake up on time. 
2) Learn to separate their breakfast time. 
3) Learn to get ready for school in proper uniform.   
4) Students will learn to create their own timetable. 

 Vocabulary: Breakfast, School, Morning, Clock, Kitchen, Help,
 Book, Clean

Opener  

What does Bunny do before going to school? 
Answer: Bunny wakes up at seven o'clock. He reads books and
does his homework. He has his morning meal. Bunny wears his
School Uniform and goes to school at 9:30. 
With a partner talk about these questions: 
At what time do you get ready for school? 
Watch the next video to learn what to do to get ready for 
school. 
Pack your bag pack for school with Amelia in the video.

Vocabulary; Instruction for text 

 Before, Breakfast, Calendar, Cupboard, Bag pack  

1) Write the meaning of the given words. 
   (You can use the looma dictionary)

2) In your notebook use the words given above in sentences 
   and in a pair discuss whether your sentence give correct 
   meaning of the word or not.

Exploration: Video about days  

There are seven days in a week: 
 Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, 
 Saturday 

What are the days you go to school? 
Answer: Sunday to Friday. Saturday is a holiday.
 
Watch the next video and learn to pronounce the name of 
days.

Assessment 

1. Make a list of things that you do before going to school.

2. Use the list that you made and prepare a routine for
 the activities you do before going to school. 

3. Write the name of days in a week. 

4. Make a list of good habits that you follow to be on time in 
school.

Reflection 

1) What did you learn from this lesson? 

2) What do you think is the purpose or importance of this 
   lesson? 

3) After completing this chapter try to make your own routine
   for your activities before school and implement them. 

4) Do you know the meaning of all the vocabulary words 
   mentioned in this chapter?

Lesson Credits

  OPENERO

ON YOUR WAY TO SCHOOL
How many different flowers and plants did you see?
What different colours of flowers did you ee?
How many colours?

 teacher.

Objectives and Vocabulary 

Objective:
By the end of the chapter students will be able to:
   1) Identify and name various flowers.
   2) Know the singular and plural form of words related
       to what we might see in a garden.

Vocabulary: garden (s)

rose (s)   beautiful,  water (noun & verb), soil   bird (s)   tree (s)

Exploration- Making Words Plural with an "S" 

When we have more than one of something , we add
the letter s to make it PLURAL. SEE the underlined words below.
Each one has an s when there is more than one.

Look at the given pictures and identify the flowers.

Name the colours you see.

More Exploration 
Now that you have learned about PLURALS WITH AN S,
can you make these GARDEN words PLURAL?
                      Example: Garden- Gardens
PLANT   many _______           PETAL  some _______
STEM    ________          FLOWER   _________
ROSE    __________        MARIGOLD ________
BIRD    _________           TREE   ___________ 

With a partner, find and name 3 objects in the room and 
make them singular (1) and plural (more than 1).

on gardens.
Look at the pictures.

How do gardens help people?

Exploration 

For fun
make the following flowers as a class.
What parts of flowers can you name?

Assessment and Reflection 

How many colours can you name in English?


What have you learned about  gardens and  flowers?
What are your favorite flowers?
What do plants & flowers need to live and grow? 
How do they help our world?

Grade 2 English -My Village 

 Objectives:  Students will:

1. Discuss issues facing your own and other's village
2. Ask questions about what you can do to help your village
3. Tell your classmates something special about your village

Vocabulary


   Active learning strategies used in this lesson are:
Group cooperative work, Brainstorm, Venn Diagram, 
                    Think-Pair-Share

Grade 2 English -My Village 

Vocabulary to Explore

TOWN      VILLAGE      CITY    HOUSE
 
SHOPS   HEALTHCARE    HOSPITAL  SCHOOL

NEIGHBORS     FRIENDS

My Village- OPENER 
CLASS BRAINSTORM
List on the board all the ideas you have to describe your village.
Is your village small or large?     Is it in the country or city?
Is it a village, town, or city? How many people live there? 
What do you love about your village?
What are your languages you hear in the village?
What do people do in the village for work?
Do you have shops or stores in your village?  

         Are there other ways to describe your village?

Grade 2 English-Exploring Vocabulary  
TOWN  A small area where people live
              with houses, services, & businesses 
VILLAGE is smaller area, usually part of a larger town

CITY-   An (urban) area with many people and businesses
Activity
   SHOUT OUT the NAME of the following pictures.
         TOWN,   VILLAGE,   CITY,   HOUSES
SHARE WITH your a partner what is different for each one. 
               Which type of place do you live?

Grade 2 English-Exploring More Vocabulary 
Learn these new words. Then find them on the next pictures.
Shops- Where people buy goods and services
Healthcare- Where a doctor or nurse help us when we have physical
             and mental health issues
Hospital-A large building providing emergency & healthcare services
Schools- A place where students and teachers gather 
             for daily learning
Friends- People & pets who you know well and regard with affection
             and trust
Neighbors- People who live near or around our home

Activity
LOOK AT the pictures following. NAME EACH PICTURE:  
              TOWN, VILLAGE, CITY , SHOPS.
SHARE WITH your a partner what is different for each picture. 
    Where do you live?     Do you have shops in your home?

ePaath Activity 

Complete the following ePaath activity about a hospital visit.

When you finish,  ask...What did I see and hear?
Have I ever visited a hospital before? Why?
Was my hospital visit helpful?
Did I get medicine?

Grade 2 English -Problems We See 

Exploration Activity: 
What problems do you think a village,town or city may have?
Are they all the same? 
What is one problem your village/town/city has? (Ask your families).

Make a class list of their answers. Discuss. 
Pick one. 
What can be done to solve the problem? Brainstorm!

Assessment 

Let's see what we have learned and how to use our vocabulary.
1) Correctly identify the differences between 
     Town, Village and City? Where do you live?
2) What public buildings are in your town or village or city?
3) Draw 3 different buildings you will find and tell what 
     they are for.
4) List 3 reasons why you might ask for healthcare.
5) When do you go to a hospital?

Reflection 

Brainstorm as a class.
What NEW WORDS did we learn?
What do you want to know more about?
WHAT problems are in your town, village or city?
How can this information be used in your community?

Grade 2 English -Keeping Clean-

         HANDS    WASH    CLEAN    DISEASE   HEALTH

 Why do we keep our HANDS CLEAN? 
   Can we get DISEASES from dirty HANDS? 
   How do DISEASES affect our HEALTH?

Instruction: Vocabulary 

Possible vocabulary activities:

A) Pairs make up story using new words & share with class.

1) Introduce the resource: 
      article, video, image, game, or group activity
2) Explain its connection with the Objectives
3) Give questions or information to the students as in 
      this video example:
Watch this video. Look for the following:

Take notes as you watch. 
Think/Write/Share: What questions do you have?
What predictions can you make about...?

Exploration: Resource Review

Ask the students to review what they learned. Include
   observations, conclusions, questions, new ideas and vocabulary
Example questions:
What did you learn about...? What are the main ideas?
What did you see concerning...?
What was the answer to the question...?
Were your predictions correct? Why or why not?
What did you conclude? What was the evidence?
How would you explain this to your friends?
What new questions do you have?

Assessment 

Students demonstrate that they have achieved the objectives
and can define and use vocabulary.
1) Do the exercises in the textbook and the exploration slides
   address all the objectives?
2) Are there activities in the textbook or exploration slides
   that assess knowledge?
3) If not, list additional tasks on this slide, such as student 
   presentations, quiz or test questions(*), or activities that
   demonstrate learning.
* Include an answer slide after question slides.

Reflection 

Encourage students to make personal connections, 
   give opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, 
   using questions like these:
What did we learn? What are the most important ideas?
What do you think is the purpose of this lesson?
What do you want to know more about?
Why to you care about...?
How these new ideas solve a problem?
How can this information be used in your community?
What do you think we will be learning next?

Introduction to Grade 2 English  
 Family 
Objectives and Vocabulary 

       When students finish the lesson they will be able to :
              1) Define what family means 
              2) Identify different family members

Vocabulary
Father, Mother,Sister, Brother, Parents, Grandparents, Cousin, Pet

                Teaching Strategies in this lesson 
Videos, pair-share, class discussion, drawing, Game-Pictionary
Vi

Opener 

Answer this question in your notebook :
How many members are there in your family? Who are they? 
         Do you have a BIG or SMALL Family?

Think carefully and discuss this question with your class: 
What does a family mean to you? What is the purpose of 
having one?

Instruction 

1) Draw a picture of your family in a plain sheet of paper.

2) After your have  completed your drawing, exchange your work 
with a partner. Share your favorite time or activity together.

3) Describe what you see in your friend's drawing.

4) Now watch this VIDEO.

Activity: Making a Family Profile 

-Make a small booklet by folding a blank sheet of paper into 
      2 parts (half). 
-Label the front page as " Family Profile. "
-Decorate the booklet cover. 
-On each page of your booklet, draw or paste a picture of each
     family member. 
 -Label each family member with the correct name
      from the following list:

Grandmother, Grandfather, Father, Mother, Me, Brother,
Sister, Cousin, My pet,

Sharing 


1. Share your FAMILY PROFILE  with your classmates.

2. Are there other family names not on our list? What are they?

3. Can you make a FAMILY TREE? Look at the next 2 examples 
          and pick your favorite.

5. Draw a family tree for your family.

Explore 

Watch the following video and play the games.

TRY THIS ACTIVITY:

2. One of you, LOOK at the following words on the next slide.

    and draw them on a blank sheet of paper.

   recitation

Objectives and Vocabulary 

         When YOU finish the lesson YOU CAN :

1) Give a short description of your family members, 
                 using descriptive words.

2) Define each family member's role in the family

3) Use new vocabulary words in conversation.
Shop, Dark, Farm, Tall, Cute

Opener 

Think carefully and discuss these questions with your class :

Do you think each of your family members is different?
In what ways are they different ?

Does each family member play a special role in the home ? 
What role?

Instruction: Read and answer 

Read together a story about a family from your teacher.
 Look for new vocabulary words while you are reading the story. 


Answer this question in your notebook :
   Can you describe with words each of your family members?

You may include their name, age, occupation and physical features.

Activity: Acrostic Poem  

A: Amazing
M: Makes me stronger
A: Affectionate 
R: Really kind

This is an example of an ACROSTIC POEM shown above. 
The poem describes the qualities of Preeti Rajbanshi's father, Amar, using
the letters of his name.

Activity: Acrostic Poem 

                        Now it is your turn.
Look at the FIRST example.

NOW make a similar acrostic poem out of one of your family 
member's name.

After you are done, recite the poem to your classroom.

Assessment 

1) Use each of your new vocabulary words in a sentence 
with a partner.
  

2) Write one interesting fact about each of your family members.
  Share some of your favourites with a partner.

Assessment 

3) Make meaningful sentences or a small skit with these words :
   Shop : a place where you buy goods 

   Dark : with little or no light 

   Farm : a place where you grow crops and animals 

   Tall : having great height

   Cute : adorable

Reflection 

List down all the new things you learned while reading
about this lesson. Reflect on words and ideas 
that you can improve on.

Lesson Credits

Introduction to Grade 2 English 
 My Uncles , Aunts and Cousins 

We will learn about our extended family (BIGGER) members:


   Active learning strategies used in this lesson are :
pair-share, classroom discussion

Opener 

Does your father or mother have any  (sisters or brothers) ?
                  If yes, what do you call them ? 

      Do you have any cousins ? Are you close with them ?

Now, look at the next slide and do the activities in it,
    first, as a class
    second, with a partner

Activity: Crossword 

Answers for the crossword puzzle : 

Across :
1. Cousin
5. Niece 

Down : 
2. Uncle
3. Nephew
4. Aunt 
 
Now, make sentences from the following words.

Activity: Family Tree with your Cousins! 

     Can you put all these people on your own FAMILY TREE?

             Cousin        Niece       Nephew

                     Uncle       Aunt

Practice 

1. Make a small play about your family at your favorite holiday.
2. Make a FAMILY TREE for your own family.
2. Explain your family members on your Family Tree to a partner.
3. Watch this next video and play the games for practice.

Assessment 

1) Look at the picture given on page 4 of your textbook. 
  Observe the surroundings and talk about Rita's family. 

2) Now it's your turn! Talk to your partner about your aunt or
   uncle. Take turns to describe each of their family members.

Assessment 

 

1) Now it's your turn! Talk to your partner about your aunt or
   uncle. Take turns to describe each of their family members.

2) NOW  tell a short story about your favorite cousins.

Introduction to Grade 2 English - My Uncles, Aunts, and Cousins 
 Objectives and Vocabulary 
We will learn about our extended family (BIGGER) members:
           When students finish the lesson they will :
1) Define the relationship with our Uncle, Aunt, and cousins.
2) Name your own uncles, aunts and cousins.
3) Add them to your family tree!

Vocabulary
Uncle, Aunt, Cousins, Niece, Nephew 

   Active learning strategies
         Drawing, Pair-share, Group discussion, Video

Introduction to Grade 2 English 
 It is  I (formal)   It is  me! (informal) 

Who am I?
What makes me happy?
Who is my family?
Where do I live?
What do I want to learn?

  Our teaching strategies for this lesson are:
        pair-share, class discussion, acting, speech bubbles

Objectives and Vocabulary 
 
   When you finish the lesson you will be able to:

          1) Give a short introduction of yourself
          2) Describe your hobbies, likes, and dislikes
          3) Give a short introduction of a friend 

Vocabulary

Myself, Family, Likes, Dislikes, Unique  Favorites Hobbies

Using your new words! 
 
Think carefully and answer these questions in your copybook :

    Describe yourself:   -- boy or girl?  --short or tall? 
           --quiet or active? --color are your eyes?
    What is something unique about you?
    What do you like to do in your free time?
    What are 3 dislikes you have? Food? Chores? Games?
 
                Draw a picture of yourself.

Instruction: Do together the lesson that follows 
 
Read each section of the next slide together.
    Do the activities together.

Make a list as a class of the new words.
    Put each new word on a small card. 
    In small groups , take 3 cards each. 
    Try to explain in your own words what it means. 
    Make up a game with your cards and share with another group.
    Put all the new words in your copybook.

Activity: Create your own Speech bubble 
 
Read and observe the " Listen and read " the last lessons;
 Tej has introduced himself, his family, his friends, his pets, 
       and his hobbies.

Now it is your turn! 
     Introduce yourself in a similar way with 
the help of speech bubbles, drawings, and pictures.

Assessment-1 

1. Define each of the following words with your classmates. 
2. All stand up. When you hear each word below,
   point to the individual or groups the word best describes.

3. With a partner, now try using these words in  sentences.

Myself   Yourself  Himself  Herself  Themselves  Ourselves
Family             Favorites             Likes           Dislikes
      Unique                                      Hobbies
  
   
   Favorite: something that I

Assessment-2 

1) Tell your partner about you.
2) Now listen to your partner.
3) What is unique about each of you?

TeGrade 2 English  Lesson 6
I Take Care of My Body

 Objectives and Vocabulary 
 
When you finish the lesson you will be able to:

1) Know how and why you need to take care of your body
2) Start to make good choices for your own body health . 

Vocabulary
Rest,  Exercise,  Balanced   Diet,  Trim,  Bathe   Safety & Danger

Opener 
 
How do you take care of your body every day?
   List to your partner all the ways from early morning until bed.
   Then share them with the class on the board.
Which ways of taking care are most common across the class?

Vocabulary

Rest, Exercise, Balanced Diet, Trim, Bath  Safety  Danger

Exploration and Assessment 

After reading the TEXTBOOK CHAPTER, in small cooperative
groups, make a "HEALTHY LIVING  PLAN" you all agree to try 
 for the next week.
Rest,  Exercise,  Balanced   Diet,  Trim, Bathe   Safety & Danger

1. Each student will keep daily record of progress
2. In one week, the group will check over and discuss your successes
 and difficulties.

What tasks were easy for each student in the group?
What tasks were difficult? Why?
What tasks would you like to change or adjust for success?


Vocabulary

Rest, Exercise, Balanced Diet, Trim, Bath  Safety  Danger

Lesson Credits

Introduction to Grade 2 English  Lesson 5 
 My Body 

         When you finish the lesson you will be able to...
             1) Identify different body parts
      2) Explain the function of different body parts

Vocabulary
Hear, Chew, Taste, Stand, Write, Brush, Comb

       Active learning strategies used in the lesson are
   class discussion, guessing game, pair-share, labeling task

Opener 

Discuss these questions with your class : 

What are the different parts of your body?
Can you name them?

What are the many things each can do?

Make a song with all the body parts.
Draw a picture of a girl or boy and label their body parts.

Explore =
Did you know you have other body parts too?

New Vocabulary to discover
joints,    muscles,    bones ,    skin,    blood,    organs

What do these do for you?
What are some of your organs inside you?

heart   lungs  brain  stomach  intestines  kidneys

Can you think of others you know?

Assessment 
 
Label the parts of the body in your copy book on your drawing.
Name the inside and outside parts you know.
What do they do?


Describe to your partner what each part can do.

Reflection 

1. With a partner, share three interesting things you learned in 
this lesson.

2.  Share ways to take care of your body.

3. What do you and your family do at home to take care
    of your body?

Introduction to Grade 2 English   
 Making a List 
 The slide order and teaching strategies of the textbook are: 
1) Objective and Vocabulary 
2) Opener: Making objective relevant and interesting personally
3) Instruction: Read textbook and practice vocabulary
4) Exploration: Practice concepts with resources and activities
   provided
5) Assessment: Prove that they can apply the learned material
6) Reflection on the lesson: Write or speak about what they 
   learned and how well they did personally 
  Active learning strategies used in the lesson are :

Objectives and Vocabulary 
 
When students finish the lesson they should be able to :

1) Understand different fruits from around the world
2) Describe different fruits from other countries

Vocabulary
Opener

Introduction to Grade 2 English- We are at School 

Let us learn together what we already know about school.
        What time do we start school?   End school?
         How do we begin our day?     End our day?
              What do we see in our classroom?
            What subjects do we study together?
     How many students do we have in our classroom?
    Active learning strategies used in this lesson are: 
        KWL, Think-Pair-Share, Singing, Acting, 
         Listening,Speaking, Reading, Writing

Objective  
By the end of the lesson students need to be able to:
1) Learn why students come to school .
2) Tell each other good habits to follow in school.
3) Explain with the school schedule and follow it.

 Vocabulary 

 count   pray   assembly   break   subject   learn  
study   read   write   listen  speak

Why are we in school? 

KWL - The teacher makes a KWL chart on the board 
   (what we KNOW ALREADY- what we WANT TO KNOW- and
          when we are finished, what we have LEARNED) . 

NOW brainstorm what you know about good habits at school. 

Discuss in pairs:
What do you go to school for and what do you learn in school?
How to understand and follow the school schedule?
What helps you to get to school on time?

Instruction 
Vocabulary Words:
 study  count   pray   assembly   break   subjects
listen   speak   write   read
   Act out and guess the meaning of each vocabulary word. 

With a partner: in your copy book, for each word: listen to the
  word, write and speak each, draw a picture, make a sentence,
              and say it to each other two times. 
Textbook lesson:
Read textbook and complete all the learning activities as a class.

What does our classroom have in it ? 

1) With a partner, name as many objects you see in the room.
2) Now share all the names in Nepali and English with your class.
3) On small cards, all students in small groups, write the names 
of the objects in English & Nepali & put each next to the objects. 
                 How many could you name?
            How many new ones did you learn?

What subjects are we studying in GRADE 2 ? 

1) With YOUR CLASS, name the SUBJECTS you are learning.
2) Make a schedule of your day & week with all your subjects listed.
3) Copy and Draw your schedule in your copy book. 

Now, with a partner- tell  your favorite subject.

Assessment & Reflection of the Lesson 

1) What are your new words in the lesson? What do you
    still need help with?
2) Describe (or draw) your new vocabulary words in a small group.
3) Can you list the different subjects in your day?
4) What are three good habits to follow at school 
       you want to remember??
5) Share these habits with your family at home.

Credits 

Lesson by: Bivisha & Joan

Teachers Intro to Grade 3 English: Unit 6 Lesson 25 
 Our Festivals 
The slide order and teaching strategies of the textbook are
1) Objectives and Vocabulary
2) Opener: Make lesson in the textbook and do activities.
3) Instruction: Read lesson in the textbook and do activities
4) Exploration: Practice with activities and resources.
5) Assessment: Prove the understanding of the lesson.
6) Reflection: Demonstrate learning. 
Active learning strategies used in this lesson are:

Objectives & Vocabulary 

When students finish this Lesson they will:

1. know different festivals celebrated in Nepal.
2. know different cultural dresses worn.
3. learn the story behind celebrating the festivals.
4. learn about different cultures and religions. 
5. learn how and when the festivals are celebrated.

Vocabulary: celebrated, culture, religion

Opener 
Discuss as a class:
In the class answer the following questions.
1) The difference between festival and culture.
2) What festival have you celebrated?
3) Why do you think people celebrate festivals?

Discuss in pairs:
Make a group of two and discuss the following questions.
1) Which festival is your favorite?
2) How do you celebrate your favorite festival?
3) Which cultural dress have you worn before?

Assessment 

1. Write two sentences each about what you observed in the
pictures.

2. Discuss the pictures with your bench partner. 

3. Make a list of questions on what you would like to learn
more.

Introduction to English Rr Phonics 1 


     Slide order of this lesson:

     1) Objectives: what a student will know and do

     2) Vocabulary: words connected to lesson

     3) Instruction: Alphabet Video Letter R

     4) Skills Practice: activities & games

     5) Assessment: how students demonstrate learning


     Active learning strategies: 

     Games, Hand Check, Cooperative Learning Groups

Objectives 


When students finish this lesson, they will:


       1. Make an upper case R and lower case r

       2. Identify the sound of r at the beginning of words

       3. Say and use five or more words that begin with r

Vocabulary 


Rr is a consonant that says its name Rr. 

These are words to learn with r at the beginning in this lesson:


Animals: rhino, rat, rabbit

                      Colors: red


Other R words:  read, raft, rose, robot, room

rice, ring, river, run, rock, rope

Exploration: Video about the letter and sound of R 


     The following video is by Jack Hartmann     

     Stand to watch this video

     Make the upper case R and lower case r in the air 

     Say the sound of r

     Listen for words that start with r

     Listen for more words that end with r

Exploration: Rr Video


How do you make an upper case R? Can you make it in the air?

Show your partner how to make a "R".

How do you make a lower case r in the air? Is it as tall as R?

Show your partner how to make r in the air.

Say R, R, R to your partner. 

Thumbs up if you can hear the r sound. 

Do you remember words from the video that start with R?


Say the r word for each picture on the following slides: 

 river, rhino, rat, rabbit, robots, read, raft, roses, rings,

 rice, red, rock, runner

Assessment 

1) How do you make a capital R and lower case r?

With a partner: Draw R and r in the air.

Give a thumbs up if your partner did it correctly! 

2) What does r sound like? What words start with r?

3) Your Alphabet Book (page after Qq):

Make a Rr page in your copybook. Write R and r at the top. 

Make pictures of 3 to 5 Rr words (optional: write the words) 

river, rhino, rat, rabbit, read, raft, roses, rings, rice, red

4) Challenge: in groups of 2 or 3, use r words to tell a story

 in 3 or 4 sequential pictures (like comic strips). For example,

 picture1: a rat in a raft on a river; picture 2 - -,  next - -.

Lesson Credits

Grade 6 English 

 Unit 2

Topics 

    1. Getting Started
    2. Reading I
    3. Speaking
    4. Listening
    5. Grammar
    6. Writing
    7. Reading II
    8. Project Work
    9. Extra Bit

Objectives 


After this Unit, you will be able to:
    - discuss what is right and wrong.  
    - ask for permission
    - set rules for your class
    - make yes/no questions
    - write profile of a famous person
Topic: Getting Started  (1 hour)

Look at the pictures that come next.

What is right or wrong with each picture?

Exploration: Right and Wrong 

What do you do in the library?

Do you make noise?

Where do you cross the road?

How do you stand in school assembly?
Sing this song together.

Listen and sing 

Would it be alright if I took your pen?
May I write and recite a poem then?
Of course, you can but rather do it soon.
I am so restless to wait till noon.

Can I take a photo with you somehow?
Is it alright if I click now?
Oh, I am afraid, I can't say 'yes' now.
Sorry, but I'd rather you not allow.

Listen and Sing 


Talk about a time when you were refused something. 

Talk in pairs and share your experiences.

1EN01.04 Listening,Speaking, Reading,Writing 

      Let's learn to listen, speak, read and write in English.

WHAT DO THESE WORDS MEAN?
 LISTENING, SPEAKING, READING, AND WRITING IN ENGLISH

            Active learning strategies used in our lesson 
Pair-Share, KWL,  Games, Hand Check,  Learning Groups,
Brainstorming, Problem Solving

1EN01.04 Listening,Speaking, Reading,Writing 

      Let's learn to listen, speak, read and write in English.

WHAT DO THESE WORDS MEAN?
WHAT ARE YOU DOING WHEN YOU DO EACH?
ACT OUT EACH WORD AND GUESS!

LISTENING-
SPEAKING
READING
WRITING

Introductions  

                       Let's introduce ourselves.
         Your teacher will demonstrate your greetings.
         Copy your teacher in pairs with a partner. 
                Then switch partners 3 times. 

 Hello.           Hi.                  How are you?    
My name is ____.        What is your name?
Good-bye.            See you soon.

Can you try these at home with your family?

Objectives 

Students, your job is to be able "TO DO" (not just "TO KNOW")
              During this lesson, show that you can:
 
                A) Greet each other.
                B) Introduce yourself to someone.
                C) Say good-bye.
                D) Learn a few colours
                E) Name your family and friends

Learning Our Colours 

     Let's put on our board all the colours we know in Nepali.
Can you find objects in the classroom matching our colors below?
Which ones can you name in English?

Make a game of paired colour cards- 2 cards for each colour- 
    ONE with just the colour, the other labeled with the word.

        RED, BLUE, YELLOW, GREEN, ORANGE, PURPLE
  
Make up your own games in pairs. Share your games with the class.

Learning Our Colours 

    Let's now watch a video on COLOUR! 
             SEE THE NEXT SLIDE.


            RED, BLUE, YELLOW, GREEN, ORANGE, PURPLE

Using the Textbook 

   The following slide is part of the textbook chapter:

          1) See what the children are saying.
          2) You do the same in your classroom.

Games to help us learn 

Try these vocabulary activities:

A) Pairs, make up a short play with your greetings share with class.
B) Students draw pictures with the correct new words.
C) Name the color of objects all around your classroom.
D) Draw a picture of your family and name them.

  (Mother, Father, Brother, Sister, Uncle, Aunt, Cousin,
 Grandmother, Grandfather)

Exploration: Let's look at videos 

=
             Watch these video. Look for the following:

1. Take notes as you watch. 
2. Think/Write/Share:
      What questions do you have?
      What predictions can you make about...?

Assessment  

1. Name the color for 3 objects in your classroom.
2. Greet 3 people in your class.
3. Tell 3 people your name in a full sentence.
4. Draw 3 family members and tell what they are to you.
5. Say good-by to 3 people.

   How did you do? What do you need more practice with?

     


      What questions do you have?
      What predictions can you make about...?

Reflection 


What did we learn?
How do we use colors in our home? In school? In our books?
Can you greet your teachers and your friends in English on your
    own?
How can the  new greetings, family names,and colors
    be used in your community?
What do you think we will be learning next?
What do you want to know more about?

Class 1 Lesson 3: Numbers 1 to 5 

What does it mean to count things?

Can you hold up 2 fingers?

How many fingers do 2 of you have together?
Count 1, 2, 3, 4 fingers! 

Then put up one more finger. 
How many do you and your partner have together?

Counting Together ! 

Count with me as you see each number 1 to 5 !
Clap your hands to show how many fingers I am holding up.

Can you stamp your feet the correct number of times?

Can you draw each number when you see it?

Activity: 1 to 5 Pictures 

Make your own pictures showing 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

You can draw things or collect things.

Label them with large, clear numbers !

Have your friend count things in your picture.

Class 1 Math 
 Order of Numbers 

Do you know the order of numbers?

Try:
What number comes after 2 but before 4?
What number comes after 7 but before 9?
data.nepali:
कक्षा १ गणित
पाठ १५: संख्या को क्रम 


के तपाईंलाई संख्या को क्रम थाहा छ ?


प्रयास गर्नुहोस्:

कुन संख्या २ पछि तर ४ भन्दा अगि आउँछ ?

कुन संख्या ७ पछि तर ९ भन्दा अगि आउँछ ?

data.html:
Order of Numbers Introduction 

To put numbers in order is to place them from lowest to highest.


The number that is greater than 2 and less than 4 is 3.

The number that is greater than 7 but less than 9 is 8.
data.nepali:
संख्या अनुक्रमको परिचय

संख्याहरूलाई क्रममा राख्‍न सबैभन्दा सानो देखि ठूलो गरी हुनुपर्छ। 


२ भन्दा ठूलो र ४ भन्दा सानो संख्या ३ हो।

७ भन्दा ठूलो र ९ भन्दा सानो संख्या ८ हो।

data.html:
Vocabulary Review 

To order numbers is to list them from lowest to highest.

Example: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
These numbers are in order.

When trying to put numbers in order, think about 
a number line and where you would put each number.
You can even write down a number line if it makes it easier.
data.nepali:
शब्दावली समीक्षा

 संख्याहरूलाई क्रममा राख्‍न तिनीहरूलाई सानोदेखि ठूलो संख्यामा सुचिबद्ध गर्नुहोस्।

उदाहरण : १, २, ३, ४, ५, ६

यी अंकहरू क्रमबद्ध छन्। 


संख्याहरूलाई क्रममा राख्दा, संख्या रेखाको बारेमा सोच्नुहोस् 

र प्रत्येक संख्यालाई तपाई कता राख्नुहुन्छ।

सजिलोपनको लागि तपाईं संख्या रेखा पनि लेख्न सक्नुहुन्छ।

data.html:
Practice Activity 

Determine whether the numbers below are in order.
If they aren't in order, rewrite them so that they are in 
order.
Use a number line if it helps you visualize.

2:    3, 4, 5, 6
3.    9, 8, 7, 5, 6
4.    1, 2, 3, 4, 5
5.    7, 8, 9, 10, 6
(The answers will be on the next slide)
data.nepali:
अभ्यास प्रश्न


तलको संख्या क्रमबद्ध छ कि छैन जाँच गर्नुहोस।

यदि तिनीहरू क्रमबद्ध छैनन् भने, उनीहरूलाई क्रमबद्ध हुनेगरि लेख्नुहोस्।

सजिलोपनको लागि संख्या रेखा प्रयोग गर्नुहोस्। 


१.   ४, १, २, ३    

२.   ३, ४, ५, ६    

३.   ९, ८, ७, ५, ६

data.html:
Practice Activity Answers 

Check your answers below:

1:   4,1,2,3 are not in order.  
They should be written: 1,2,3,4

2:  3,4,5,6 are in correct order.

3:  9,8,7,5,6 are not in order.
They should be written: 5,6,7,8,9
data.nepali:
अभ्यास प्रश्नका उत्तरहरू


आफ्नो उत्तर जाँच गर्नुहोस् :


४.   १, २, ३, ४, ५ क्रममा छन ।

 

५.   ७, ८, ९, १०, ६ क्रममा छैन ।

सही उत्तर  ६, ७, ८, ९, १० हो ।

data.html:
Practice Activity Answers 

Finish checking your answers below:

4:    1, 2, 3, 4, 5 are in order.

5:    7, 8, 9, 10, 6 are not in order.
They should be written as 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.

Review of Order of Numbers 

5, 6, 7, 8 are in number order.

6, 8, 5, 7 are not in number order because they
 do not go in ascending or increasing order. 
They do not go from the lowest number to the highest.

To put numbers in order, 
you must place them from least to greatest.
data.nepali:
संख्याहरूको क्रमबद्ध समीक्षा

 

५, ६, ७, ८  संख्याहरू क्रम मा छन्।


६, ८, ५, ७ संख्याहरू क्रम मा छैनन् किनभने तिनीहरू

 बढ्दो क्रममा छैनन्।

तिनीहरू सबैभन्दा सानो संख्या देखि सबैभन्दा ठूलो संख्यामा जादैन।


अंकहरू क्रममा हुन, तपाईंले तिनीहरूलाई सानो अंक देखि ठूलो अंकमा राख्नु पर्छ।

Order of Numbers

Guiding Questions:
